    <item>
      <title>I, Daniel Blake review: Ken Loach's welfare state polemic is blunt, dignified and brutally moving</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/i-daniel-blake-ken-loachs-welfare-state-polemic-is-blunt-dignified-and-brutally-moving</link>
      <description><p>There are shades of Dickens and Orwell in this emphatic drama about a disabled man strangled by the red tape of the benefits system</p><p>With this movie — <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/may/02/ken-loach-jimmys-hall-changes-mind-about-retirement">maybe his last, and maybe not</a> — Ken Loach establishes himself yet further as the John Bunyan of contemporary British cinema. Based on research and interviews by the screenwriter Paul Laverty, this movie tells the fictional story of Daniel Blake, a middle-aged widower in the North East who can’t work or get benefits after a near-fatal heart attack, and the story is told with stark and fierce plainness: unadorned, unapologetic, even unevolved. Loach’s movie offends against the tacitly accepted rules of sophisticated good taste: subtlety, irony and indirection. The film is not objective, and perhaps the Loach and Laverty have signed up to Churchill’s maxim about not being neutral between the firemen and the fire.</p><p>Ken Loach will insist on behaving as if there really is something urgently wrong, and that we shouldn’t or needn’t get used to food banks as a fact of life; he portrays it all as something which we might actually do something about in the real world, as opposed to invoking injustice as an aesthetic gesture, or a flavour-ingredient of modern social realist fiction. Many are happy to concede the value of films like this set in the developing world, showing sympathetic people trying to retain their dignity while being hungry. But the same thing set in modern Britain gets dismissed with an embarrassed shrug as strident or hectoring, as if going hungry is impossible for British non-shirkers. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/i-daniel-blake-ken-loachs-welfare-state-polemic-is-blunt-dignified-and-brutally-moving">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘Movie blood tastes so good’ – on The Neon Demon set with Nicolas Winding Refn</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/movie-blood-tastes-so-good-on-the-neon-demon-set-with-nicolas-winding-refn</link>
      <description><p>In his first horror movie, Drive director Refn puts Elle Fanning through hell as a young model in LA. Ahead of the film’s premiere at Cannes, we go behind the scenes</p><p>In May 2015, in the basement of a haunted house in Silver Lake, Los Angeles, one woman chases another with murderous intent. Under deep red light, she wields a poker. At a staircase, they struggle. The second woman falls, holding a gleaming Psycho-style kitchen knife. There is silence.</p><p>“Let’s do one more.” A few feet away, Nicolas Winding Refn looks up from scene 118, take four of his film, The Neon Demon. The crew unfreeze, a dozen figures in headphones. The women wander back to where they had started. The poker was carried by actor Abbey Lee, the knife by body double Joanna Bennett. Lee wears a white trouser suit, Bennett a ruched white dress. She is identical in every way to the film’s star, Elle Fanning, who watches nearby: same dress, same long blonde hair, the same tiny coloured jewels around their eyes. For a moment, they stand beside each other.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/movie-blood-tastes-so-good-on-the-neon-demon-set-with-nicolas-winding-refn">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jodie Foster: 'I think this is the most risk-averse period in movie history'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/jodie-foster-cannes-money-monster-film-hollywood</link>
      <description><p>In Cannes, the actor and director of Money Monster addressed the lack of female directors in mainstream Hollywood, saying ‘studio executives are scared’</p><p>“I’m not a spokesman for anything – I know nothing,” Jodie Foster declared in Cannes on Wednesday, in front of a room of press attending her Kering Women in Motion talk. But over the course of her hour-long conversation with Variety’s Ramin Setoodeh, she proved herself wrong, passionately advocating on behalf of fellow female directors. </p><p>The actor and film-maker is in Cannes to premiere her fourth feature as director, Money Monster, outside of competition. She previously directed 1991’s <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102316/reference">Little Man Tate</a>, 1995’s Thanksgiving comedy <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0113321/reference">Home for the Holidays</a> and 2011’s Mel Gibson vehicle, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/may/17/cannes-2011-the-beaver-review-mel-gibson">The Beaver</a>. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/jodie-foster-cannes-money-monster-film-hollywood">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Woody Allen responds to Ronan Farrow: 'I never read anything about me'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/woody-allen-ronan-farrow-cannes-cafe-society-film</link>
      <description><p>The film-maker, at Cannes with his new film Café Society, spoke with press at a lunch about his son’s article and the rape joke made at his expense during the opening night ceremony</p><p>Woody Allen’s opening night film of the 69th Cannes film festival, Cafe Society, has been generally well-received by critics. But Wednesday’s kick-off to the event was by no means smooth for the 80-year-old film-maker.</p><p>The morning of the premiere, a piece by Ronan Farrow, Allen’s estranged son, ran in the Hollywood Reporter, restating his support for his stepsister, Dylan, who has in the past claimed Allen sexually assaulted her as a child. Later, in introducing the film at the Lumiere cinema, master of ceremonies Laurent Lafitte shocked the audience when he addressed a joke to Allen, saying: “It’s very nice that you’ve been shooting so many movies in Europe, even if you are not being convicted for rape in the US.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/woody-allen-ronan-farrow-cannes-cafe-society-film">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>George Clooney: Donald Trump will not become president – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/12/george-clooney-donald-trump-president-cannes-video</link>
      <description><p>Actor <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/georgeclooney">George Clooney</a> <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/george-clooney-donald-trump-jodie-foster-money-monster-cannes-2016">weighed into the presidential election</a> during a press conference at the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/cannes-2016">Cannes film festival</a>, stating that ‘there’s not going to be a President <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/donaldtrump">Donald Trump</a>’. Clooney told the gathered reporters that Trump would not win as the American people are ‘not afraid of Muslims or immigrants or women’, and would not be ruled by fear</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/12/george-clooney-donald-trump-president-cannes-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why I won't be seeing Woody Allen's new film | Melissa Silverstein</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/woody-allen-film-cafe-society-cannes</link>
      <description><p>As a culture, we pay too little attention to women’s claims of abuse. The accusations leveled at Allen are serious enough to justify a boycott</p><p>There are <a href="http://blogs.indiewire.com/womenandhollywood/kering-and-cannes-film-festival-will-present-second-women-in-motion-program-20160321">panels</a> about the plight of women in film all across the Cannes Film Festival, which opened Wednesday. Yet the festival has no issue welcoming someone who’s been accused of molestation to the red carpet.</p><p>Woody Allen’s new movie, Cafe Society, kicked off proceedings. Insiders saw the movie before Allen walked the carpet at the official premiere, but I was not there, because I refuse to see his movies – refuse to support a man whose own children allege that he molested his daughter Dylan, and who makes films that treat women like objects (Allen strongly denies the sexual abuse allegations leveled at him).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/may/12/woody-allen-film-cafe-society-cannes">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>George Clooney: 'There’s not going to be a President Donald Trump'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/george-clooney-donald-trump-jodie-foster-money-monster-cannes-2016</link>
      <description><p>The Money Monster star asserted that Trump would fail to win the US presidential election because ‘fear is not going to drive our country’</p><p>George Clooney has said that Donald Trump will not win the US presidential election as the American public will not be ruled by fear.<br></p><p>“There’s not going to be a President Donald Trump,” he said. “Fear is not going to drive our country. We’re not afraid of Muslims or immigrants or women. We’re not going to be afraid of anything.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/george-clooney-donald-trump-jodie-foster-money-monster-cannes-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Money Monster review - George Clooney goes Leslie Nielsen in popcorn hostage thriller</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/money-monster-review-george-clooney-jodie-foster-cannes-2016</link>
      <description><p>The Jodie Foster-directed satire about the financial meltdown isn’t especially original, but it’s arguably more honest than Oscar favourite The Big Short</p><p>A miasma of pure silliness settles on this movie directed by Jodie Foster, showing here in Cannes out of competition; it deserves a genre of its own: screwball action. Julia Roberts plays a harassed TV producer who has to keep in line her waning star: Lee Gates, played by George Clooney, the ego-crazed, silver-fox presenter of a TV show called Money Monster, giving stock picks and spurious shock-jock-type commentary on the market, celebrating unfettered capitalism by breaking into embarrassingly geriatric hip-hop moves with backing dancers. (He reportedly bears a certain resemblance to a real-life pundit: Jim Cramer, presenter of a programme called Mad Money, on CNBC.) </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/money-monster-review-george-clooney-jodie-foster-cannes-2016">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>When it comes to interracial romances, the movies need to catch up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up</link>
      <description><p>Almost 50 years after Kirk and Uhura’s kiss on Star Trek, there are plenty of parts for black women - provided they want to play blue- or green-skinned aliens …</p><p>“Interspecies love is in the air!” enthuses <a href="http://teaser-trailer.com/warcraft-movie-anduin-lothar-and-garona-halforcen/">one movie fansite</a> at the prospect of the forthcoming Warcraft movie.</p><p>There’s a lot to get up to speed with in Warcraft. The original video games were so wildly popular that their community of players exceeds the population of Norway, and the <a href="http://wowwiki.wikia.com/wiki/Portal:Main">World of Warcraft wiki</a> has over 100,000 pages. For novices, it’s a fantasy world not far removed from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/lord-of-the-rings">Lord of the Rings</a> or Dungeons and Dragons: a realm of elves, dwarves, mythical creatures and medieval weaponry. Warcraft the movie revolves around Azeroth, a kingdom apparently ruled by European humans. Azeroth is invaded by orcs: hulking, relatively primitive ogres with overdeveloped lower canines. Rather than open arms, Azeroth greets these refugee orcs with medieval arms. “They’re beasts. They should all be destroyed,” says one character. It’s essentially a race war, although the battle lines are by no means cut and dried, so there’s still room for a bit of interspecies love.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/may/12/when-it-comes-to-interracial-romances-the-movies-need-to-catch-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Everybody Wants Some!! review – Richard Linklater's sports jock comedy is a winner</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/everybody-wants-some-review-richard-linklaters-sports-jock-comedy-is-a-winner</link>
      <description><p>Nothing much happens, but that’s the point in this beautifully observed exploration of what it’s like to be young and male</p><p>In his <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/oct/16/before-sunrise-sunset-romance">Before Sunrise</a> movies, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/richard-linklater">Richard Linklater</a> got audiences to hang out with people who were talkative, idle, interested in sex and clever. In Everybody Wants Some!!, he gets you to hang out with people who are talkative, idle, interested in sex and, erm, not quite as clever as all that. Yet it is a deceptively subtle comedy, and also a challengingly and almost provokingly unironic film intensifying and cartoonifying what it is like to be young and male, but quite without the obviously readable drama and poignancy of his earlier film <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jul/10/boyhood-review-richard-linklater-film">Boyhood</a>, that now legendary real-time movie tracking a young man’s growing pains.</p><p>A bunch of corn-fed sports jocks are on baseball scholarships at a Texas college some time in the 1980s, macho, sex-obsessed and as innocent as children. They listen to MOR rock: the title is taken from a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everybody_Wants_Some!!">Van Halen track</a>, and the muscular bass-guitar octave jolts of the Knack’s My Sharona kick the film off as the chief character drives his car down the streets, checking out the ladies. Later, he and his friends will cram into a car and sing along word-perfect to the Sugarhill Gang’s <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rapper%27s_Delight">Rapper’s Delight</a>, like Mike Myers’s Wayne and his friends singing to Bohemian Rhapsody, and just as ridiculous.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/everybody-wants-some-review-richard-linklaters-sports-jock-comedy-is-a-winner">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Adam McKay defends Ronald Reagan 'Alzheimer’s comedy'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/adam-mckay-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy-will-ferrell</link>
      <description><p>The Big Short director says ‘deification of Reagan’ is responsible for backlash against the Will Ferrell film plans </p><p>The Oscar-winning film-maker Adam McKay has defended plans for a controversial comedy about Ronald Reagan suffering from Alzheimer’s disease after his producing partner <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/will-ferrell-backs-out-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy">Will Ferrell was forced to step away</a> from the project in the wake of rightwing outrage.</p><p>Adam McKay, known for The Big Short and Anchorman, was due to produce Reagan through the Gary Sanchez production company he runs with Ferrell. The erstwhile Saturday Night Live comic was in line to play the former president, but walked away following a media furore.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/adam-mckay-ronald-reagan-alzheimers-comedy-will-ferrell">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Assassin's Creed: five things we learned from the first trailer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-trailer-analysis-michael-fassbender</link>
      <description><p>Michael Fassbender’s movie already looks better than Warcraft, with Marion Cotillard on top femme fatale form and director Justin Kurzel embracing the video game</p><p>Along with Duncan Jones’s Warcraft it’s been billed as the video game movie that might just make us forget all about the cinematic crimes of Uwe Boll and his ilk, that can induce glorious amnesia for those struggling to wipe clean memories of Prince of Persia, Hitman or Lara Croft Tomb Raider: The Cradle of Life.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/12/assassins-creed-trailer-analysis-michael-fassbender">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

    <item>
      <title>The secret lives of movie-star newborns: who are they, and what is all that goo?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/secret-lives-of-moviestar-babies-hollywood</link>
      <description><p>Thousands of barely sentient beings are trying to make a name in Hollywood, a place where you can always look younger – even if you’ve just been born</p><p>“Here comes another piece of action,” says the doctor, who is not a doctor. “It’s crowning!”</p><p>We see a hairless vagina that is not a vagina splitting a small wet skull that is actually not a – well, you get the point: none of this is real.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/secret-lives-of-moviestar-babies-hollywood">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Kill Command review – superior sci-fi action thriller</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/kill-command-review-superior-sci-fi-action-thriller</link>
      <description><p>The performances are cool and the plot’s a blast in Steven Gomez’s watchable drama about a military exercise that takes a terrible turn</p><p>Steven Gomez is a visual effects supervisor who has graduated to writing and directing his first full-length feature. It’s a sci-fi action thriller whose borrowings are very plain, but it’s decent and watchable nonetheless, with an interesting central character premise. </p><p>Reprising much of the style and hardware of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/the-terminator">Terminator</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/robocop">Robocop</a>, Gomez gives us the story of some US Marines who in the future are ’coptered to a remote location for training. With them is a young civilian observer called Mills (Vanessa Kirby) who is part android, having been “cured” of paralysis as a child by a sinister corporation that implanted in her head new software and artificially created brain matter: this is the same tech that runs the battle drones she is there to inspect.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/kill-command-review-superior-sci-fi-action-thriller">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cabin Fever review – horror remake astounding in its lameness</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/cabin-fever-review-horror-remake-astounding-in-its-lameness</link>
      <description><p>A gang of young people encounter creepy hillbillies and a flesh-eating virus in this uninspired rehash of Eli Roth’s 2002 scary movie</p><p>Eli Roth presides as exec producer over this fantastically pointless and uninspired horror remake of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/News_Story/Critic_Review/Guardian_review/0,4267,1059453,00.html">his 2002 scary movie</a> about the attractive young people who go away for a weekend break in a cabin in the woods, have sex and then succumb to a flesh-eating virus, while at the same time being menaced by creepy hillbilly locals. </p><p>There is no interesting new slant on this material: it’s just the same old stuff, being served up in a tired and cynical fashion, without anything inventive in the way of humour or fear. And the sting that comes midway through the closing credits takes the film to a new level of lameness and dullness. One to avoid.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/cabin-fever-review-horror-remake-astounding-in-its-lameness">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Our Kind of Traitor review – Ewan McGregor gets smart in Le Carré potboiler</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/our-kind-of-traitor-review-ewan-mcgregor-le-carre-potboiler</link>
      <description><p>This is meat-and-potatoes Le Carré given a generic spy-movie treatment, but still it reels you in</p><p>The insecurity of the modern world has brought John le Carré back out of the shadows. Following <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/sep/15/tinker-tailor-soldier-spy-film-review">Tinker Tailor</a> redux, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/sep/11/a-most-wanted-man-review-philip-seymour-hoffman">A Most Wanted Man</a> and the crackerjack hokum of TV’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/series/the-night-manager-episode-by-episode">The Night Manager</a>, this mid-list potboiler finds the author trading shamelessly on western suspicions about Mother Russia, tossing troubled couple Naomie Harris and Ewan McGregor into the geopolitical cut-and-thrust after they befriend vodka-gulping heavy Stellan Skarsgård during a make-or-break Moroccan getaway. </p><p>Director Susanna White favours a generic spy-movie look: those chilly blue filters surely need resting now. Yet she works smartly with her actors: while Skarsgård wolfs down great handfuls of scenery, McGregor effectuates a thoughtful transformation from ineffectual tourist to man in the field. Not even the gifted adaptor Hossein Amini (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/may/15/the-two-faces-of-january-review-highsmith-kirsten-dunst">The Two Faces of January</a>) can convince us it’s anything more than second-string le Carré – meat and potatoes, where others have brought us caviar – but we’re still reeled in, patiently and capably.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/our-kind-of-traitor-review-ewan-mcgregor-le-carre-potboiler">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The meal deal: Woody Allen, Jessica Chastain and Kirsten Dunst at the Cannes opening dinner</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/cannes-2016-woody-allen-jessica-chastain-and-kirsten-dunst-opening-dinner</link>
      <description><p>After the red-carpet screening of Allen’s latest, Café Society, the great and good of the Cannes film festival assembled for a lavish banquet in the Palais</p><p>Woody Allen was the first one in and the first one out at Wednesday’s kick-off dinner for the 2016 Cannes film festival, held immediately following the opening night screening of the film-maker’s 47th movie, Café Society. A romantic comedy set in the mid-1930s, Café Society features a bevy of glamorous party scenes that would feel right at home in a Baz Luhrmann production. But on the first night of the 69th edition of the festival, the famously reclusive director looked like he wanted to be anywhere else than at the big event.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/gallery/2016/may/11/cannes-2016-woody-allen-kristen-stewart-blake-lively-in-pictures">Cannes 2016 day one: Woody Allen, Kristen Stewart and Justin Timberlake – in pictures</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/cannes-2016-woody-allen-jessica-chastain-and-kirsten-dunst-opening-dinner">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/hollywood-sexism-probe-wide-ranging-well-resourced-aclu</link>
      <description><p>American Civil Liberties Union hopes historic investigation will lead to charges against producers who fail to hire female directors</p><p>A historic federal probe into alleged sexist hiring practices in Hollywood has resulted in a “wide-ranging and well-resourced investigation”, according to the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU).</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/07/us-hollywood-discrimination-prejudice-female-directors-equal-opportunities">Hollywood prejudice against female directors to have US equal opportunity inquiry</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/hollywood-sexism-probe-wide-ranging-well-resourced-aclu">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Estranged son of the film director has said the media has not pressed his father enough over sexual abuse allegations made by his adopted daughter Dylan in the 1990s</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/woody-allen-cannes-film-festival-cafe-society-artistic-competition">Woody Allen at Cannes: artistic competition 'against common sense'</a> </p><p>The estranged son of Woody Allen, Ronan Farrow, has condemned the media for its handling of decades-old sexual abuse allegations against the film director, hours before his latest film opened at the Cannes film festival.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/ronan-farrow-condemns-media-woody-allen-allegations">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Captain America: Civil War review – an aspartame rush</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/captain-america-civil-war-review-an-aspartame-rush</link>
      <description><p>Entertaining mayhem ensues when some of the Avengers reject government oversight following a botched operation</p><p>Should the Avengers be nationalised? This is the explosively controversial idea that ignites a “civil war” among their ranks in this exciting superhero extravaganza. It’s crazily surreal, engaging and funny in the best Marvel tradition, building to a whiplash-twist reveal that sports with the ever-present idea of duplicity and betrayal within the Avengers’ ranks themselves.<br></p><p>The innumerable civilian deaths and collateral damage that always follow the Avengers’ spectacular city-pulverising showdowns have become impossible to ignore – and now the Avengers are faced with having to submit to UN political oversight and control. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/captain-america-civil-war-review-an-aspartame-rush">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dheepan review – a crime drama packed with epiphanic grandeur</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/07/dheepan-review-jacques-audiard-palme-d-or</link>
      <description><p>Jacques Audiard’s confident Palme d’Or-winner has a rare and keen interest in its characters – a trio of Tamil refugees in Paris – and an exhilarating mastery of style</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/03/jacques-audiard-interview-dheepan-prophet-rust-done-director">Jacques Audiard: ‘I wanted to give migrants a name, a shape… a violence of their own’</a> </p><p>There is such exhilarating movie mastery in this powerful new film about Tamil refugees in France from director <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/03/jacques-audiard-interview-dheepan-prophet-rust-done-director">Jacques Audiard</a>, who gave us <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/jan/21/a-prophet-review">A Prophet</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/nov/01/rust-and-bone-review">Rust and Bone</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2005/nov/04/1">The Beat That My Heart Skipped</a>. It’s bulging with giant confidence and packed with outbursts of that mysterious epiphanic grandeur, like moments of sunlight breaking through cloud-cover, with which Audiard endows apparently normal sequences and everyday details. There is also something not always found in movies or books or TV drama – that is to say, intelligent and sympathetic interest in other human beings. Every scene, every line, every frame has something of interest. All of it is impeccably crafted and the work of someone for whom making films is as natural as breathing.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/07/dheepan-review-jacques-audiard-palme-d-or">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A Bigger Splash review – Tilda Swinton and Ralph Fiennes plumb the depths of desire</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/11/a-bigger-splash-review-tilda-swinton-ralph-fiennes-luca-guadagnino</link>
      <description><p>In Luca Guadagnino’s simmering drama, two ex-lovers are disastrously reunited at a Mediterranean villa where the pool is a temple of bared flesh and sex perfumes the air</p><p>Luca Guadagnino assembles a very intimidating quartet for this chamber piece of sexual tension. It’s a very stylish and engaged remake of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/sep/29/la-piscine-film-review">Jacques Deray’s 1969 psychological thriller La Piscine</a> (The Swimming Pool). The new title brings in the swoony blueness of David Hockney’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/jonathanjonesblog/2016/feb/10/an-even-bigger-splash-why-david-hockneys-pop-art-poem-lives-on">painting</a> and alludes also to the unsubtle male competition at work in these poolside encounters.</p><p>Wealthy and worldly, his characters are broadly the same as in the 1969 film, which is transplanted from the South of France setting to the Italian island of Pantelleria off the Sicilian coast. The action takes place in a gorgeous villa with a swimming pool, way up in the hills and far from the harbour where increasing numbers of migrants are being held. Tilda Swinton plays Marianne, a globally famous rock star currently in retreat from the madness of her world, happily vacationing with her partner, Paul (Matthias Schoenaerts), a would-be documentary film-maker. They are both wounded in some way, but happy in each other’s company.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/11/a-bigger-splash-review-tilda-swinton-ralph-fiennes-luca-guadagnino">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Rabin, the Last Day review – form and structure hamper Israeli PM murder story</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/17/rabin-the-last-day-review-israel-netanyahu-amos-gitai</link>
      <description><p>Docudrama about the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin takes aim at Netanyahu, but puts stylistic cinema above propaganda</p><p>Amos Gitai won’t be receiving any gifts from prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu next <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2014/mar/18/the-jewish-festival-of-purim-in-pictures">Purim</a>. His new film, Rabin, the Last Day, minces no words and charges him as morally culpable for the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/oct/30/yitzhak-rabin-israel-far-right">assassination of Yitzhak Rabin</a>. Not that Netanyahu personally called Rabin a Nazi or carried a coffin in effigy (others did that), but he and his wave of rightwing politics fanned the flames of sedition after the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oslo_Accords">Oslo Accords</a>. A movie with a charge this extreme, and the courtroom scenes that convincingly connect the dots, ought to make for a major international discussion. But that discussion is unlikely to happen, because this isn’t the work of Michael Moore or Oliver Stone. This is Amos Gitai: an iconoclast at times, but an artist first.<br></p><p>Gitai has chosen stylistic cinema over propaganda, and he is a director who regularly gets bogged down a bit in form. Rabin, the Last Day is no different. It dispenses with a traditional three-act structure or main characters. It opens with a lengthy new interview with <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/10/shimon-peres-what-you-need-to-know-israel-president">Shimon Peres</a>, then blends news footage from 1995 and legal scenes that are almost stage-read with slow, contemplative imagined sequences. It’s essentially a pastiche, a sketch study for a grand painting that never arrives. Some moments are chilling, others are deliberately dull; part of an effort, I believe, to intentionally lull the audience into a somnambulant state for some larger metatextual reason. The end result is frustrating; however, Gitai is so committed to his own process this might even be the goal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/17/rabin-the-last-day-review-israel-netanyahu-amos-gitai">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Dark Horse: The Incredible True Story of Dream Alliance review – it’s a winner</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/apr/16/dark-horse-the-incredible-true-story-of-dream-alliance-review</link>
      <description>This likable documentary traces the story of the barmaid in a Welsh village pub who persuaded her regulars to fund a racehorse<p>With its sheer warmth and likability, this good-natured documentary won my heart – a real-life The Full Monty or Billy Elliot or Pride. In 2000, Jan Vokes was a barmaid and part-time Asda cleaner in the Welsh village of Cefn Fforest, a place depressed both economically and emotionally. Jan conceived the idea of organising a syndicate to breed a racehorse: drinkers in the bar would get a share in return for a weekly £10 sub.</p><p>Her funding model was genius. When Jan and her fellow owners cheerfully rocked up at posh racing meets, toffee-nosed types would mock. But their horse, Dream Alliance, showed them what was what.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/apr/16/dark-horse-the-incredible-true-story-of-dream-alliance-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Being Charlie review – spoiled rich kid grows up in inspiring rehab drama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/05/being-charlie-review-rob-reiner-inspiring-rehab-drama</link>
      <description><p>Director Rob Reiner’s comeback film, based on a screenplay by his son, is packed with cliches about teenage drug addiction, but not without charm</p><p>Critics frequently cite <a href="http://movies.stackexchange.com/questions/16997/what-is-the-source-of-truffauts-famous-anti-war-movie-quote ">François Truffaut’s theory</a> that there can never be a true anti-war film. I’d like to extend this to the much smaller genre of films about young kids of privilege who get stuck in drug rehabs or mental wards. What adolescent <em>doesn’t</em> want to scowl and spit in the face of square adults who just don’t get it? Moreover, these boys (it’s almost always boys) brood their way right into the hearts and arms of understanding, sexy girls who also refuse to do what society says. What a blast! From <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0055892/reference">David and Lisa</a> to <a href="http://www.focusfeatures.com/its_kind_of_a_funny_story">It’s Kind of a Funny Story</a> (making stops along the way with scenes from <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0081283/reference">Ordinary People</a> and lesser known movies like <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0252684/reference">Manic</a>) I’m usually left in a reverie, half-wishing I could ditch the worries of the real world, go back in time, cozy up inside of an institution and find the love of a carefree, unorthodox girlfriend. (This is probably something I should speak to a counselor about.)</p><p><a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt4630444/reference">Being Charlie</a>, the newest film from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/jul/28/rob-reiner-still-planning-princess-bride-musical">Rob Reiner</a> based on a somewhat autobiographical screenplay by his son Nick, puts all the others to shame for making teenage drug addiction look so appealing. Not the intention, I’m sure, but dammit I don’t care what society dictates: I tell you the truth!</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/05/being-charlie-review-rob-reiner-inspiring-rehab-drama">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>

    <item>
      <title>Mother’s Day review – almost transcendentally terrible</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/mothers-day-review-jennifer-aniston-julia-roberts-jason-sudeikis</link>
      <description><p>Surely destined to become a camp classic, this movie features the likes of Julia Roberts and Jennifer Aniston spouting unintentionally hilarious dialogue</p><p>As a critic I’m frequently given the unenviable task of reporting on a bad film. Time and again hopeful people often ask, “yes, but is it so bad that it’s actually good?” and almost always the answer is, “no, no, it’s just plain bad.” But not this time. If this were a just world, someone like <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/jun/30/john-waters-art-lassie-justin-bieber-ansel-adams">John Waters</a> will end up presenting this film at midnight screenings as audiences, dressed in character, hurl rejoinders at the screen. Mother’s Day, Garry Marshall’s third in an unofficial trilogy that includes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/feb/11/valentines-day-film-review">Valentine’s Day</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/dec/08/new-years-eve-film-review">New Year’s Eve</a>, is a goddamn trash masterpiece.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/mothers-day-review-movie-critics-julia-roberts-garry-marshall-">Mother's Day gets the mother of all critical maulings</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/mothers-day-review-jennifer-aniston-julia-roberts-jason-sudeikis">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Keanu review – Key and Peele disappoint with violent feline comedy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/13/keanu-review-key-and-peele-disappoint-sxsw</link>
      <description><p>The titular cat is best thing about the first film by the comedic duo that bears little of the wit that made their Comedy Central show such a sensation</p><p>“This feels like a five-minute sketch that’s outstayed its welcome,” grumbled a journalist sitting next to me at SXSW’s “work in progress” screening of Keanu, the first big-screen vehicle for Comedy Central sensations Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/09/sxsw-film-movie-schedule-keanu-pee-wee-herman">SXSW Film: the most-anticipated movies from Keanu to Pee-wee</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/13/keanu-review-key-and-peele-disappoint-sxsw">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Ratchet & Clank review – game spin-off running on empty</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/ratchet-clank-review-animation</link>
      <description><p>Another good video game has its soul removed to fit a factory-line animation template, but it fills 90 mins for kids if they’ve seen everything else</p><p>Converted from the Sony console game, this latest factory-line animation so insistently generates intergalactic spectacle that it tramples its own message about rejecting grand gestures and doing the right thing. As our plucky hero progresses from self-doubting cadet to resistance top gun, the animators prove rather better at rendering hovercars and bogey-guns than original ideas, repurposing key narrative and design elements from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/pixar">Pixar</a>, TV’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2009/sep/25/futurama-your-next-box-set">Futurama</a>, and perhaps even the old Super Nintendo shoot-’em-up Starfox. Again, it’ll fill a screen and kill 90 minutes if the kids have seen everything else – surely its biggest hope – but the ratio of hardware to heart badly needed another tune-up.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/ratchet-clank-review-animation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Family Fang review: Jason Bateman and Nicole Kidman are siblings with issues – likewise the film</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/15/the-family-fang-review-jason-bateman-and-nicole-kidman-are-siblings-with-issues-likewise-the-film</link>
      <description><p>The actor is back with his second effort as director, and the first real indication the promise audiences sense in him may never be fulfilled</p><p>The received wisdom about Jason Bateman is that his work is unworthy of him. That this is an actor of great sympathy and sardony, who gamely makes the most of parts in movies that are beneath him. He was in Toronto last year with This is Where I Leave You, a film that, like Horrible Bosses and The Change-Up and The Switch and countless others, finally played out like a cry for help. </p><p>He was also here a couple of years ago with his first attempt to save himself: directorial debut Bad Words, in which he played a man who uses a loophole to register for – and triumph at – a spelling bee competition. It was mucky and bitter: a little predictable, but shot through with enough snark and bite to offer a glimpse of how his career could be. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/15/the-family-fang-review-jason-bateman-and-nicole-kidman-are-siblings-with-issues-likewise-the-film">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Man Who Knew Infinity review – treacly maths drama doesn't quite add up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/the-man-who-knew-infinity-review-dev-patel-jeremy-irons</link>
      <description><p>Dev Patel is maths genius Srinivasa Ramunujan and Jeremy Irons his Cambridge mentor in this well-intentioned movie</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/mathematics-movies-the-man-who-knew-infinity">Genius by numbers: why Hollywood maths movies don't add up</a> </p><p>This well-intentioned drama centres on the extraordinary, little-known story of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/mathematics-movies-the-man-who-knew-infinity">Srinivasa Ramunujan</a>, a young Indian man at the beginning of the last century whose untrained genius for pure mathematics and a staggering volume of original work produced unaided and outside the academic system stunned the fellows of Trinity College, Cambridge to whom he had been introduced by his mentor, the distinguished mathematician GH Hardy. Ramunujan battled the reactionary conservatism and racism of the British establishment to become accepted: he is played by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/feb/21/dev-patel-didn-t-know-what-getting-into-slumdog-marigold-hotel">Dev Patel</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/24/jeremy-irons-have-natural-tendency-benign-dictator-batman-v-superman">Jeremy Irons</a> portrays Hardy; Toby Jones plays Hardy’s kindly colleague John Littlewood; Jeremy Northam contributes a cameo as the twinkly-eyed radical Bertrand Russell. It’s a film with its heart in the right place, but the problem of how to represent mathematical problems on screen is not really solved – the recent <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/mar/12/x-plus-y-charming-story-of-mathletes-in-love">X+Y</a> managed better. At the end, it looks like a treacly, albeit high-minded Sunday afternoon drama serial.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/the-man-who-knew-infinity-review-dev-patel-jeremy-irons">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Viva review – Cuba-set drag queen drama doesn't shirk its punches</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/05/viva-review-drag-queen-paddy-breathnach-telluride</link>
      <description><p>Director Paddy Breathnach finds a set of strong performances from his Cuban cast for this feelgood film set in a seedy Havana</p><p>Irish director Paddy Breathnach is far from the first film-maker to seek inspiration in the lives of a troupe of drag queens, but with Viva, shot and set in Cuba, he calls on a set of remarkable performances to wring something vivid and often fresh out this narrative of redemption. Jesus is an 18-year old hairdresser living on his own in rundown Havana, scraping a living out a handful of elderly clients, but is drawn to the seedy glamour of the local drag queen bar. One afternoon, he finds a stick of lipstick left in his apartment by his friend, the neighborhood tart, who has borrowed the place because there’s nowhere else she can find to have sex with her boxer boyfriend. Jesus paints his lips red, tries pouting in the mirror, and scoots to an audition for a role at the bar with its (male) mother hen, played superbly by Luis Alberto Garcia.<br></p><p>Jesus gets the gig, but no sooner has he adopted the stage name of Viva and hit the spotlight than he’s assaulted by a stranger who’s lurking in the darkness: this is his father, Angel (Jorge Perugorría), last seen 15 years ago and returned from prison. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/05/viva-review-drag-queen-paddy-breathnach-telluride">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Papa: Hemingway in Cuba review – Hollywood's Havana horror</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/27/papa-hemingway-in-cuba-review-hollywoods-havana-horror</link>
      <description><p>The first Hollywood film to be shot in Cuba since Castro isn’t close but no cigar – the Ernest Hemingway biopic is an oceangoing embarrassment</p><p><a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2749282/reference">Papa: Hemingway in Cuba</a> holds the distinction of being the first Hollywood production to shoot on the island nation since 1959. But other film-makers looking to leave their mark need not fret, as there’s still an opportunity to make the first American film shot there since Fidel Castro came to power that isn’t a complete, mortifying embarrassment.</p><p>Papa is another biopic-through-the-lens of a young acolyte, similar to<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/nina-simone-biopic-review-zoe-saldana"> the recent debacle Nina</a>, though this time its screenplay was written by the witness himself. Giovanni Ribisi is Ed Myers (name changed from the late Denne Bart Petitclerc), a newspaperman in Miami in the late 1950s. Abandoned by his father at a young age, as we’re told through lugubrious narration, he turned to the books of Ernest Hemingway while looking for a father figure. He writes an impassioned note to Hemingway and one day he receives a phone call. “I got your letter. It’s a good letter,” Adrian Sparks’s Hemingway tells him, as if he didn’t see the parody of Hemingway in Woody Allen’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/oct/06/midnight-in-paris-film-review">Midnight in Paris</a> – or, worse, he <em>did</em> see it and used that as a guide. “You like to fish?”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/27/papa-hemingway-in-cuba-review-hollywoods-havana-horror">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>

      <title>The Huntsman: Winter's War review: dud follow-up to a film no one liked</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/04/the-huntsman-winters-war-review-dud-followup-to-a-film-no-one-liked</link>
      <description><p>Now Snow White is awol, this dreary and incoherent CGI mashup of plots from Frozen, Narnia and The Incredibles really cannot justify its existence<br></p><p>Here it is: the least keenly anticipated prequel-slash-sequel of the year. It is the follow-up that nobody much wanted to the film that nobody much liked, resulting in something even more visually elaborate and boring, and about which the number of tosses that can be reasonably given is lower than ever. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/may/31/snow-white-and-huntsman-review">Snow White and the Huntsman – review</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/04/the-huntsman-winters-war-review-dud-followup-to-a-film-no-one-liked">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Elvis & Nixon review: Michael Shannon resurrects the King</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/elvis-nixon-review-michael-shannon-1970-meeting</link>
      <description><p>The actor underplays Presley to great effect in Liza Johnson’s entertaining imagining of the legendary meeting between the president and the rock icon</p><p>The meeting between Richard M Nixon and Elvis Presley on 21 December 1970, is so legendary that the photograph that immortalized the moment is still the most requested image in the National Archives. It’s a wonder, then, that it’s taken this long to imagine their summit on screen.</p><p>Writers Joey Sagal, Hanala Sagal and Cary Elwes take major artistic liberties to retell the story of that the encounter and the events leading up to it in <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2093991/reference">Elvis &amp; Nixon</a>, a breezy comedy nimbly directed by Liza Johnson (Hateship Loveship).</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/elvis-nixon-review-michael-shannon-1970-meeting">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/15/the-meddler-susan-sarandon-rose-byrne-review</link>
      <description><p>An overbearing mother who moves closer to her daughter after her husband’s death must find another outlet for her intensity in this sweet crowd-pleaser</p><p>You might not be aware, but it’s not that easy for women over the age of 60 to get work in Hollywood. Unless you’re Meryl Streep or you’re happy to play “grandma with fart problem”. Even a fine actor like Susan Sarandon has struggled. While she’s had small roles in good movies like Robot &amp; Frank and Arbitrage, the last time she had a lead role in a great movie was her Oscar-winning performance in 1995’s Dead Man Walking. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/15/the-dressmaker-kate-winslet-liam-hemsworth-review">The Dressmaker - Kate Winslet is stitched up in oddball revenge drama</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/15/the-meddler-susan-sarandon-rose-byrne-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tale of Tales review: monarch of the gran</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/13/tale-of-tales-review-eat-your-heart-out-for-matteo-garrones-royally-nasty-fairytale</link>
      <description><p>Cannes already has a standout movie: the horrific new Renaissance fairytale from Gomorrah director Matteo Garrone. Features scenes of flea-petting, heart-eating and a right royal hag-shagger</p><p>Matteo Garrone’s Tale of Tales is fabulous in every sense: a freaky portmanteau film based on the folk myths collected and published by the 16th-century Neapolitan poet and scholar Giambattista Basile – Garrone worked on the adaptation with Edoardo Albinati, Ugo Chiti and Massimo Gaudioso.<br> <br> It is gloriously mad, rigorously imagined, visually wonderful: erotic, hilarious and internally consistent. The sort of film, in fact, which is the whole point of Cannes. It immerses you in a complete created world.<br> <br> Ovid is mulched in with Hansel, Gretel, the Beauty, the Beast, the Prince, the Pauper, in no real order. At times, Garrone seemed to have taken inspiration from Michelangelo Antonioni’s own fabular tale The Mystery of Oberwald – at others, it felt like he had deeply inhaled the strange and unwholesome odour still emanating from Walerian Borowczyk’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2014/may/08/immoral-tales-film-you-should-watch-video">Immoral Tales</a>. But there’s also a bit of John Boorman’s Excalibur, Monty Python and the Holy Grail, Blackadder, The Company of Wolves, the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/books/2014/jan/11/my-hero-john-tenniel-chris-riddell">Tenniel illustrations</a> for Alice in Wonderland… and Shrek.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/13/tale-of-tales-review-eat-your-heart-out-for-matteo-garrones-royally-nasty-fairytale">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hockney review – at the shallow end</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/27/hockney-review-documentary-painter-art</link>
      <description>From the hi-tech iPad art to the paintings of shimmering swimming pools, this film portrait is an amiable celebration of David Hockney, but it never goes quite deep enough<br /><p>Randall Wright’s docu-portrait of David Hockney, arguably Britain’s greatest living artist, is an amiable, agreeable study – as engaging and undemanding as a magazine profile with a great photo spread. It’s an attractive introduction or reintroduction to the man and his work, and to his remarkable experimentalist curiosity and readiness to pioneer new media. I&nbsp;knew about <a href="http://www.hockneypictures.com/photos/photos_polaroids.php" title="">Hockney’s Polaroid mosaics</a>, but until now I had never seen what you might call the 2.0 upgrade: he drives along, videotaping the countryside with nine digital cameras in fixed positions, producing a&nbsp;mesmeric chequerboard collage of moving pictures in fractionally misaligned frames. Hockney has used fax machines, colour photocopiers, iPhones and iPads to create art. It is fascinating.</p><p>The film reminded me of the thrilling boldness and scale of Hockney’s work, from his pop-art classic <a href="http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/hockney-a-bigger-splash-t03254" title="">A Bigger Splash</a> from 1967 to his colossal landscape <a href="http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/hockney-bigger-trees-near-warter-orou-peinture-sur-le-motif-pour-le-nouvel-age-post-t12887" title="">Bigger Trees Near Warter</a> from 2007. Although his art&nbsp;is accessible and exciting, I would have liked to hear more in-depth critical study or even a few dissentient voices. For example, my colleague Adrian Searle, who <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2012/jan/16/david-hockney-landscapes" title="">has been agnostic about the later, spectacular canvases</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/27/hockney-review-documentary-painter-art">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>A Hologram for a King review – Tom Hanks presides over meandering mess</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/a-hologram-for-a-king-review-tom-hanks-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p> Hanks is stellar playing an exasperated businessman waiting in Saudi Arabia to meet with the region’s king in hectic adaptation of Dave Eggers’s novel</p><p>Tom Hanks is an inherently likable actor. Hell, he was <a href="http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/10/25/tom-hanks-most-likable-man-hollywood_n_4163462.html">voted</a> “the most trusted person in America” in a 2013 poll. It’s next to impossible not to fall prey to his everyman charms, and it’s solely thanks to these that his latest film, A Hologram for a King, is watchable.</p><p>Based on Dave Eggers’s best-seller about an exasperated American businessman who ventures to Saudi Arabia for a pitch-meeting with the region’s monarch, Tom Tykwer’s adaptation is a meandering mess of half-baked storylines that amount to little. Hanks’s affable presence keeps it all afloat.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/a-hologram-for-a-king-review-tom-hanks-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Jungle Book review – spectacular revival of Disney's family favourite</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/the-jungle-book-review</link>
      <description><p>Hyperreal digital animation meets old-fashioned storytelling in this faithful remake, which loses the songs but brings new, ingenious twists on the original</p><p>What on earth is the point of remaking Walt Disney’s great and possibly greatest masterpiece, the glorious animated musical from 1967, based on Kipling’s tales, all about the “man cub” Mowgli, brought up by wolves in the Indian jungle – famously the last film to get Disney’s personal touch? A remake which furthermore leaves old-fashioned animation behind, departing for the live-action uncanny valley of hyperreal CGI, which heretically loses most of the songs and which also abandons the original’s final, unforgettably exotic glimpse of a real-life human girl? </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/the-jungle-book-review">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <pubDate>Tue, 12 Apr 2016 13:53:28 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/the-jungle-book-review</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/21e05658bb9ee5ac2e8e65e1d7c13e5321eb3f55/857_0_4140_2485/4140.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=88d0f24adcf4c69192f8e7349978cae8">

      <title>Criminal review – body-swap sci-fi goes horribly wrong</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/14/criminal-review-ryan-reynolds-kevin-costner</link>
      <description><p>Ryan Reynolds and Kevin Costner swap bodies in this extremely ridiculous and unpleasantly violent science-fiction thriller</p><p>What is it with Ryan Reynolds and body-swap movies? He had one in the comedy <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2011/sep/15/the-change-up-film-review1">The Change-Up</a> (2011), as a single guy who switches identities with Jason Bateman’s uptight married man, and another in the sci-fi thriller <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/16/selfless-review-ben-kingsley-ryan-reynolds">Self/Less</a> (2015), playing a young soldier whose firm young body is bought by an ageing, lizardly plutocrat played by Ben Kingsley. Now it’s happening again, in this ridiculous and unpleasantly violent thriller directed by Ariel Vromen. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/14/criminal-review-ryan-reynolds-kevin-costner">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sing Street review - teen zero to hero in three chord wonder from Once director</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/25/sing-street-review-teen-zero-to-hero-in-three-chord-wonder-from-once-director</link>
      <description><p>Once director John Carney hits the bullseye again with a goodnatured 80s-set comedy about a timid schoolkid who starts a band to impress a beautiful girl</p><p>Did you like The Commitments? Did you like We Are the Best!!? Well, Sing Street isn’t as good as either of those two, but it’s still pretty terrific.</p><p>A new kid at school (Ferdia Walsh-Peelo) spies a fashionably dressed, somewhat sullen older girl&nbsp;Raphina (Lucy Boynton) standing alone on a stoop and musters the courage to speak to her. She’s a model, she says, and prepping a move from Dublin to London. He asks her to be in his music video and, after some cajoling, she agrees. The only problem is that he doesn’t have a band yet.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/25/sing-street-review-teen-zero-to-hero-in-three-chord-wonder-from-once-director">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Boss review – unfunny adventures in capitalism with Melissa McCarthy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/the-boss-review-melissa-mccarthy</link>
      <description><p>McCarthy’s disgraced tycoon deals in cheap jokes in a foul-mouthed caper that swats at suburbia, salesmanship and girl-scouting, directed by the star’s husband</p><p>The evidence is more than circumstantial: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/30/melissa-mccarthy-paul-feig-spy">Paul Feig</a> is the Melissa McCarthy-whisperer. Like cooking with rosemary or incorporating tubas into a piece of music, casting the abundantly talented McCarthy in a leading film role takes a very delicate hand. Feig directed her to hilarious effect in Bridesmaids, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/01/the-heat-review">The Heat</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jun/04/spy-review-melissa-mccarthy-hotshot-heroine">Spy</a> and will hopefully do so again later this year in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/mar/04/five-things-we-learned-from-the-new-ghostbusters-trailer">Ghostbusters</a>. Unfortunately, he was nowhere to be found while the cameras were rolling on The Boss, an unfunny, chaotic mess of ludicrous plotting and tone-deaf set-pieces that’s as bad as her 2013 abomination <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/mar/21/identity-thief-review">Identity Thief</a>.</p><p>As in that earlier film (which, it must be said, was a tremendous financial success, just in case you needed another reason to weep for the world) McCarthy is a near-sociopath loner that has a particular skillset, but is otherwise completely out of touch with the real world. (She’s never heard of a Dorito before.) When we meet her trimly coiffed, turtleneck-wearing exec Michelle Darnell, she boasts to a packed stadium of acolytes of being one of the richest women in the world, and hawks a “program” to help them make money. This side of her business is never mentioned again, and is just one of dozens of examples of the loose-strings twirling all over the place in the haphazard script written by McCarthy, director Ben Falcone and Steve Mallory.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/06/the-boss-review-melissa-mccarthy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Demolition review - Jake Gyllenhaal's muddled quirkfest crashes into emptiness</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/11/demolition-review-jake-gyllenhaal-muddled-quirkfest-crashes-emptiness-tiff</link>
      <description><p>An investment banker struggles to grieve for his wife in this Toronto film festival opener while as an audience, we struggle to care</p><p>Jean-Marc Vallée could be quite easily categorised as an “actor’s director”. His last two films notched up two acting Oscars and a further two acting nominations between them (Dallas Buyers Club and Wild) so it’s therefore easy to understand why talent would be drawn to his next project. But Jake Gyllenhaal and Naomi Watts will surely be left feeling a little flattened by Demolition, a frustratingly aimless soul-search that veers uncomfortably between quirk and melancholy.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/audio/2016/apr/26/the-year-in-flops-so-far-and-demolition-reviewed-the-dailies-film-podcast">The year in flops so far and Demolition reviewed – the Dailies film podcast</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/11/demolition-review-jake-gyllenhaal-muddled-quirkfest-crashes-emptiness-tiff">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Hardcore Henry review – plotless, characterisation-free cinema du Xbox</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/18/hardcore-review-ilya-naishuller-plotless-cinema-du-xbox-toronto-tiff</link>
      <description><p>Director Ilya Naishuller’s gory, first-person action film is like a video game in which we leap, climb, kill and find ourselves bored silly</p><p>For folks who are too lazy to play their own video games, there’s the movie Hardcore. For 90 minutes, first-time feature director Ilya Naishuller throttles your central nervous system with a stretched-out spasm of first-person action. Run here, jump there, slice this carotid artery, shatter that skull. The plot, what little of it there is, has mute amnesia victim Henry (ostensibly “you”), avoiding death at every turn and frantically racing to a series of checkpoints delivered to his phone by a reappearing guide in the form of a manic (and homophobic) Sharlto Copley.</p><p>From an acrobatic point of view, all the GoPro choreography is impressive. “How’d they do THAT?” you’ll wonder for the first 15 minutes. But as the relentless shaky-cam and ear-splitting weapons blasts soldier on, this query changes to: “Do I have any aspirin in my bag?” Hardcore taps into a 14-year-old boy’s brain, marinating in a vat of Mountain Dew, fantasising about high-energy kills, lusty women and loud music. Perhaps interesting for sociological study, but as a movie, it is vulgar, boring and embarrassing.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/18/hardcore-review-ilya-naishuller-plotless-cinema-du-xbox-toronto-tiff">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Louder than Bombs review: muffled English-language debut by Joachim Trier</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/18/louder-than-bombs-review-muffled-english-language-debut-by-joachim-trier</link>
      <description><p>A few bright scenes involving Jesse Eisenberg as a callow new father can’t redeem this weirdly pointless drama with Isabelle Huppert as a war photographer and Gabriel Byrne her accomodating husband</p><p>Norwegian film-maker Joachim Trier and his longtime screenwriter Eskil Vogt – a director himself – won golden opinions at Cannes in 2011 with their film Oslo, August 31<sup>st</sup>, which showed in the Un Certain Regard sidebar. Now they have stepped up to the main Competition with a contrived family drama in the English language, portentously entitled Louder Than Bombs. The resulting noise turns out to be a bit muffled and very anti-climactic: a rather silly, pointless and directionless film.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/audio/2016/apr/19/tighter-rules-on-golden-globes-comedy-and-louder-than-bombs-reviewed-the-dailies-film-podcast">Tighter rules on Golden Globes comedy and Louder than Bombs reviewed –&nbsp;the Dailies film podcast</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/18/louder-than-bombs-review-muffled-english-language-debut-by-joachim-trier">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>God's Not Dead 2 review – only brief instances of transcendent badness</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/01/gods-not-dead-2-review-pure-flix</link>
      <description><p>The latest from evangelical production company Pure Flix is a dull courtroom drama, but unlike the previous film, it isn’t quite silly enough to be entertaining</p><p>When conversation turns to the entertainment value of the recent “faith-based” films aimed at the US evangelical market, inevitably someone will say: “Nothing tops that Kevin Sorbo one.” The picture in question is God’s Not Dead, an <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/apr/17/gods-not-dead-review">outrageously slapdash, inarticulate movie</a> filled with ludicrous plotting, inelegant staging and one of cinema’s most absurd endings. (The big bad atheist gets hit by a car, just as the Christian rock band Newsboys tells everyone in the audience to text their friends that God isn’t dead.) Shot for only $2m, it grossed more than $60m, enabling its production company, Pure Flix, to release follow-ups such as <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/mar/20/do-you-believe-first-look-review-predictable-christian-sales-pitch">Do You Believe?</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/03/faith-of-our-fathers-review-hard-to-keep-the-faith-in-pureflixs-worst-film-yet">Faith of Our Fathers</a>. But franchises are the thing right now, so it’s not surprising that Pure Flix’s most bankable title would rise again. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/apr/17/gods-not-dead-review">God's Not Dead review – warped evangelist drama</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/01/gods-not-dead-2-review-pure-flix">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Meet the Blacks review – an angry and unapologetically gutter-mouthed comedy</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/01/meet-the-blacks-review-angry-and-unapologetically-gutter-mouthed-comedy</link>
      <description><p>While there is a whiff of social commentary in this low-budget spoof of the 2013 horror The Purge, only a comic performance from Bresha Webb provides any impact</p><p>“Daddy, they Purgin’!” So shouts Bresha Webb, whose comic performance in the ultra low-budget Meet the Blacks is so unpredictable and versatile it virtually makes up for the film’s many dull patches. Webb, who is 28 but plays the teen daughter of Carl Black, has a range that zips from Judy Holliday-like ditz to an antic, Kevin Hart-style faux toughie over the course of just one scene. That’s probably not a good indicator of the film’s overall consistency, but considering how ridiculous this movie is, ditching credibility for the higher cause of a laugh at any price is probably the right decision. Meet the Blacks is an asinine film (though with a kernel of seriousness) but whenever it feels like it is running out of steam, something strange and surreal will happen to elevate it above a typical spoof movie.</p><p>Despite assembling a talented group of performers, director Deon Taylor and his co-writer Nicole DeMasi have aimed low. Meet the Blacks mimics the 2013 horror/action movie The Purge, which has had a bigger cultural impact than I realised. Spoof movies are frequently safe to write off, but Meet the Blacks is not A Haunted House, the wretched though financially successful Marlon Wayans vehicle that parodied Paranormal Activity. This is an angry, unapologetically gutter-mouthed nasty comedy, and while the plot may mirror something current, the vibe is more akin to classic 1970s independents such as Rudy Ray Moore’s <a draggable="true" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gzd2XY0Giyg">Petey Wheatstraw</a>. It isn’t polished, but it has an urgency.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/01/meet-the-blacks-review-angry-and-unapologetically-gutter-mouthed-comedy">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>What We Become review – unoriginal Danish zombie outbreak film lacks bite</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/what-we-become-review-danish-zombie-horror</link>
      <description><p>Mildly interesting zombie outbreak picture set in suburban Denmark offers a familiar theme with local variants – such as really slick interior furnishings</p><p>Once when traveling in a small city in the Middle East my wife and I waited too long to have dinner. Every restaurant was closed, except for one: McDonald’s. We sure as hell didn’t want to eat their burgers, but we tried to find a positive spin. Let’s see what McDonald’s is like in this part of the world.</p><p>It’s with this level of cultural curiosity surrounding less-than-enticing options that you should approach What We Become, a wholly unoriginal but mildly interesting zombie outbreak picture set in suburban Denmark. It’s the same low-budget horror flick you’ve seen many times before, but it’s nice to see some local variants on a familiar theme.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/what-we-become-review-danish-zombie-horror">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Pelé: Birth of a Legend – biopic of soccer's greatest is a terrible own goal</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/pele-birth-of-a-legend-brazil-soccer-star-biopic</link>
      <description><p>A predictable and ham-fisted kids’ flick appears to be the aim of this attempt at committing the story of the Brazilian football great to celluloid, and it shows</p><p>In Star Wars – the first one – Luke Skywalker knows he’ll never be able to blow up the Death Star until he shuts down the fancy equipment on his X-Wing fighter, lets himself go and uses the Force. So it is with Pelé, the soccer star, who must disregard the Eurocentric obsessions of his coach and team captain, embrace his innate Brazilian gifts, and destroy those French jerks (and even nastier Swedes) who stand in the way of national glory.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/pele-birth-of-a-legend-brazil-soccer-tribeca-film">Pelé: Birth of a Legend continues the soccer star's big screen legacy</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/pele-birth-of-a-legend-brazil-soccer-star-biopic">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/pele">Pelé</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/football/football">Football</category>

    <item>
      <title>The Last Laugh review – can the Holocaust ever be funny?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/the-last-laugh-review-holocaust-jokes-documentary-mel-brooks-sarah-silverman</link>
      <description><p>Documentary asks survivors as well as comedians including Mel Brooks and Sarah Silverman to consider whether it’s right to make jokes about death camps<br></p><p>Did you hear the one about the murder of 6 million Jews? In the documentary <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2102508/">The Last Laugh</a><strong>, </strong>writer and director Ferne Pearlstein canvasses comedians ranging from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2015/mar/23/mel-brooks-review-solo-show-convivial-reminder-nostalgia">Mel Brooks</a> to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/sarah-silverman">Sarah Silverman</a>, Holocaust survivors and anti-racism activists to ask whether the Nazi death camps are an appropriate subject for humour. <br></p><p>Naturally, this gives rise to an incredible wealth of comic material ranging from <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M2lfZg-apSA">Seinfeld’s Soup Nazi</a> (which Roz Weinman, who was in charge of standards and practices for NBC at the time, regrets approving as she believes the way it passed into pop culture ended up trivialising the Holocaust) to<a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2013/02/28/joan-rivers-under-fire-for-heidi-klum-holocaust-joke/1955033/"> Joan Rivers’s 2013 shock-and-awe one-liner about Heidi Klum</a>: “The last time a German looked this hot was when they were pushing Jews into ovens.” <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/the-last-laugh-review-holocaust-jokes-documentary-mel-brooks-sarah-silverman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>King Cobra review: James Franco at his lurid best in gay porn shocker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/gay-porn-star-king-cobra-review-james-franco-brent-corrigan</link>
      <description><p>The actor gives his most unhinged performance since Spring Breakers in Justin Kelly’s compelling film detailing the rise of porn star Brent Corrigan</p><p>As an actor, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/james-franco">James Franco</a> has two modes: committed and can’t-be-bothered. His bold work in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/apr/04/spring-breakers-review">Spring Breakers</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/127-hours">127 Hours</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/pineapple-express">Pineapple Express</a> falls into the first category; <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/mar/07/oz-the-great-and-powerful-review">Oz the Great and Powerful</a> and Werner Herzog’s misbegotten Queen of the Desert meanwhile feature Franco at his most lifeless. Luckily for film-maker Justin Kelly, Franco is at his brazen best in the dark gay porn saga <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5129682/reference">King Cobra</a>.<br></p><p>The film reunites the star with the director of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jan/25/sundance-2015-review-i-am-michael-james-franco">I Am Michael </a>for another gay-themed narrative based on real events. That, however, is where the similarities end.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/gay-porn-star-king-cobra-review-james-franco-brent-corrigan">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>LoveTrue review:  dreamy, evocative – and just a bit dull</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/lovetrue-review-dreamy-evocative-dull-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>This Israeli director’s film, backed by Shia LaBeouf, follows a pensive stripper, busker and surfer – but while well shot, their stories just aren’t that interesting</p><p>What is love? It’s a question that has vexed thinkers from Plato to <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HEXWRTEbj1I">Haddaway</a>. Israeli director Alma Har’el, whose roots lie in music videos and art installations, makes no claim on knowing the answer, but is persistent in repeating the question. If the chatter at this year’s Tribeca film festival is to be believed <a href="https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/lovetrue-2016">LoveTrue</a>, Har’el’s latest, was <a href="http://www.indiewire.com/article/tribeca-alma-harel-and-shia-labeouf-premiere-hypnotic-footage-from-lovetrue-20150417 ">financed without the consultation of lawyers</a> after<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/nov/11/shia-labeouf-allmymovies-angelika-film-center-new-york"> the increasingly art-adjacent Shia LaBeouf</a> became a fan of the director since her last picture, the hallucinatory portrait of a California ghost town, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/feb/02/bombay-beach-ghost-town">Bombay Beach</a>.</p><p>LoveTrue is a portrait of three individuals who share no connection other than being unhappy. Blake is a big-hearted young stripper in Alaska, who finds tremendous empowerment and gratification in her job, but worries that she’ll be trapped in it forever. She finds herself unable to maintain lengthy relationships, and the man she loves, who suffers from a rare bone disease that makes physical intimacy difficult, is drifting away. Will is a young surfer and coconut salesman in Hawaii raising a young son whose biological parents, he learns, are actually his difficult ex-girlfriend and former friend. Despite no legal or even ethical responsibility to raise the child, the bond is already there. Finally there is Victoria, a member of a family of New York City buskers who live with their father after their mother leaves due to his chronic adultery. Though relations are strained, the family sing Christmas carols with a determination to raise enough money to keep her out of homeless shelters.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/lovetrue-review-dreamy-evocative-dull-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>
