    <item>
      <title>Burden review – how a crazed performance artist mellowed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/chris-burden-documentary-film-review-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>The late Chris Burden was known for works involving extreme physical peril, but he ended up almost respectable. A compelling new film charts his journey</p><p>It’s a strange path from nailing oneself to a revving Volkswagen to creating a photo-ready oasis of nostalgic, tourist-friendly street lamps. This was the journey of <a href="http://www.chrisburdenfilm.com/">Chris Burden</a>, the sculptor and performance artist whose early, notorious work pushed even the most liberal responses to the unanswerable question “what is art?” Luckily, <a href="http://www.chrisburdenfilm.com/">Burden, a documentary</a> from Timothy Marrinan and Richard Dewey, is a thorough enough guide that even skeptical audiences may find themselves “getting it”.</p><p>The story gets cooking at the University of California at Irvine in 1969, where Burden, having shrugged off a potential career in architecture, is studying sculpture. It’s a time and a place where traditional notions of what sculpture means are, shall we say, flexible. Recollecting for us in interview footage shot shortly <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2015/may/11/chris-burden-sculptor-and-performance-artist-dies-aged-69-at-home-in-california">before he died last year</a>, Burden, without ever explaining the <em>what</em> of his work, gets us in his head as to the <em>why</em>. Observing sculpture is inherently active; one moves in space around the piece. This movement, therefore, becomes part of the piece, so action itself becomes sculpture. Incorporate the artist into this and you have something. Incorporate the artist doing something dangerous and you have something people will <em>talk</em> about.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/chris-burden-documentary-film-review-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Vincent-N-Roxxy review – lurid violence lifts aimless romance</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/vincent-n-roxxy-review-lurid-violence-lifts-aimless-romance</link>
      <description><p>Emile Hirsch and Zoë Kravitz’s talents are wasted in an inane love story that only springs to life during its bloody final reel</p><p>For a film called <a href="https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/vincent-n-roxxy-2016">Vincent-N-Roxxy</a>, Gary Michael Schultz’s two-hander seems oddly uninterested in the love story at its core. </p><p>After an energetic opening sequence that sees the titular twosome, played by Emile Hirsch and Zoë Kravitz, meet under the most chaotic of circumstances, the pair drift for much of the rest of the film until Schultz attempts to liven matters with an extended bout of extreme violence. It’s only then that Vincent-N-Roxxy springs to visceral life. Pity that the bloody finale only makes up for the last third of what’s otherwise pretty dreary.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/vincent-n-roxxy-review-lurid-violence-lifts-aimless-romance">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Banksy Job review – old street art spat makes tedious viewing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/banksy-job-review-tedious-viewing-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>The theft and return of the celebrated street artist’s sculpture is treated like a major art heist in a film that riffs on Banksy’s Exit Through the Gift Shop</p><p>This film dredges up an unsurprisingly long-forgotten news story and stretches it out mercilessly to 90 minutes. In March 2004, Banksy’s first sculpture – a version of Rodin’s The Thinker with a traffic cone on his head and retitled The Drinker – was taken from the central London plinth where the street artist had left it and “kidnapped”. In December, more than a decade later, <a draggable="true" href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3356875/Banksy-s-sculpture-Drinker-returned-ten-years-stolen-art-activists-added-special-twist-scrawled-p-plinth.html">it was returned to the same spot</a>, only now the statue was seated on a toilet and retitled The Stinker. </p><p>Sophisticated stuff, barely registering on the scale of art heists given that the work was a) totally unguarded and b) pretty much worthless, both financially and artistically. (Even Banksy himself only offered £2 for its return.) Yet this film approaches this leaden caper as if it’s <a href="http://metro.co.uk/2014/12/08/5-most-audacious-art-heists-of-all-time-4978677/">Vincenzo Peruggiab stealing the Mona Lisa from the Louvre</a> – instead of an amazingly charmless Yorkshireman, styling himself as an “art terrorist” called AK47, pinching the sculpture because he’s upset that Banksy wouldn’t sign a print he bought. The poor love. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/banksy-job-review-tedious-viewing-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Phenom review: baseball movie throws a curveball</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/the-phenom-review-baseball-ethan-hawke</link>
      <description><p>Ethan Hawke impresses as an abusive father to a major-league rookie pitcher in an intriguing character study that’s admirably hard to pin down </p><p>From its graceful opening credits sequence, which, backed by an elegant classical music score, fixes the viewer’s gaze on some tasteful wallpaper, writer and director Noah Buschel’s <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3885524/reference">The Phenom</a> immediately goes out of its way to subvert all the expectations associated with baseball movies.</p><p>Despite its rigorously formal leanings, The Phenom is still a film about a young man struggling to regain his focus and grow into the athlete he was born to be. But unlike <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/mar/26/the-film-that-makes-me-cry-field-of-dreams">Field of Dreams</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/movie/107576/bad.news.bears">Bad News Bears</a>, <a href="http://www.sportsonearth.com/article/50216396/">Bull Durham</a> and countless other films centered on the sport, The Phenom is more interested in its hero’s psychological trappings than his talents on the field.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/the-phenom-review-baseball-ethan-hawke">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Custody review: Viola Davis stamps authority on courtroom drama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/custody-review-viola-davis-hayden-panettiere-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>A fine cast, including Hayden Panettiere, animates this deeply wrought film about the lives of three strangers that intersect in a New York family court</p><p>The courtroom drama Custody opens rather clumsily, with writer/director <a href="http://jameslapine.com/">James Lapine</a> choosing to spell out his title to the audience, as if worried they’re somehow unaware of its meaning.</p><p>“Cus·to·dy: the protective care or guardianship of someone or something,” reads a title card. You don’t say.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/custody-review-viola-davis-hayden-panettiere-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Ticket review: Dan Stevens goes from blind saint to sighted monster</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/the-ticket-review-dan-stevens-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>The former Downton Abbey star excels as a family man who becomes an arrogant villain – but the film-makers don’t know what to do with his transformation</p><p>Imagine you’re blind, then one morning you wake up having inexplicably regained your eyesight. How would that change you? Affect your loved ones? Alter the course of your life? </p><p>As conceived by writer/director Ido Fluk in his stylish, slow-burning psychological drama <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3893280/reference">The Ticket</a>, that scenario would spell your doom. Admirably cynical until it loses its way in the final stretch, The Ticket nevertheless maintains a provocative allure, bolstered by a fiercely committed performance from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2014/aug/30/dan-stevens-no-more-mr-nice-guy-downton-abbey">Dan Stevens</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/the-ticket-review-dan-stevens-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>National Bird review – chilling film reveals truths about drones</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/17/national-bird-review-us-drones-program-tribeca-film-festival</link>
      <description><p>Using the testimony of three courageous whistleblowers who worked on the US drone programme, this documentary uncovers some disturbing truths about modern American warfare<br></p><p>This is a disturbing documentary which, through the testimonies of three courageous whistleblowers, sheds some daylight on the USA’s secret military drone programme. Directed by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/15/sonia-kennebeck-us-air-force-drone-war-home-roosthttp://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/15/sonia-kennebeck-us-air-force-drone-war-home-roost">Sonia Kennebeck</a> and executive-produced by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/mar/04/wim-wenders-retrospective-five-to-watch-one-to-miss">Wim Wenders</a>, National Bird weaves together the stories of the air force veterans Lisa, Daniel and Heather, all of whom have worked on the drones programme, gathering intelligence and tracking targets to be killed. <br></p><p>Then National Bird moves to Afghanistan, where the maimed survivors of a mistaken drone strike on unarmed civilians in February 2010, which killed 23 people, describe what happened when they were attacked. The juxtaposition of the appallingly gung-ho attitude of the drone operatives, re-enacted from a transcript of the event, and raw footage of the dead bodies (some children) returning to their anguished friends and family, is heartbreaking and enraging. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/17/national-bird-review-us-drones-program-tribeca-film-festival">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Strike a Pose review – Madonna's dancers vogue back in anger</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/17/strike-a-pose-film-review-madonna-dancers</link>
      <description><p>Picked to dance on the star’s Blond Ambition tour, then starring in the hit documentary Truth or Dare, Madonna’s boys struggled with the aftermath</p><p>There’s something very meta about this film – it’s almost a documentary about a documentary. In 1990, at the height of her imperial phase, a conical bra-clad <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/14/madonna-review-pop-queen-pole-dances-high-kicks-and-bigs-up-mike-tyson">Madonna</a> hit the road with her <a href="http://www.people.com/article/madonna-blond-ambition-25th-anniversary">Blond Ambition</a> tour. Sharing her stage were seven super-buff, and extremely talented, male dancers. Blond Ambition’s lashings of sex and religion made it a cause célèbre<em> </em>– <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eR1J6WK0dhE">the Vatican described the show as satanic</a> – and the ever-enterprising Madonna managed to milk the controversy the following year, too. Filmed backstage, her documentary <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102370/">Truth or Dare </a>(aka In Bed With Madonna) featured scenes of the star and those dancers bitching, snogging and, in Madonna’s case, performing oral sex on a wine bottle. As one contemporary news report declared in shock: “There are even scenes with two men kissing!”</p><p>That news report is revisited in <a href="https://tribecafilm.com/filmguide/strike-a-pose-2016">Strike a Pose</a>, which takes those dancers and what happened to them afterward as its subject. All but one were gay (the straight man was the New Orleans hip-hop dancer Oliver Crumes III), and none were white. Two of them, Jose Gutierez and Luis Camacho, were plucked straight out of New York’s vogueing scene, the underground gay dance world which inspired Madonna’s hit Vogue. Strike a Pose reveals that three of them had also been diagnosed with HIV before they joined the tour, back when that equated to being informed that you would die a premature and horrible death. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/apr/17/strike-a-pose-film-review-madonna-dancers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>All We Had review: Katie Holmes wows in her meandering directorial debut</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/16/all-we-had-review-katie-holmes-wows-in-her-meandering-directorial-debut</link>
      <description><p>A stellar, brazen performance by the Dawson’s Creek actor and her strong cast keep this film, about the bond between a wayward mother and daughter, afloat</p><p>Katie Holmes directs herself in All We Had, an adaptation of Annie Weatherwax’s popular novel, and delivers the strongest performance of her career. At 37 years old, the former Dawson’s Creek star is a welcome revelation.</p><p>In what marks her most worthwhile role since playing the titular scarred young woman in the 2003 film Pieces of April, Holmes throws herself into portraying Rita, a drug and alcohol addict and homeless mother to a young teen.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/16/all-we-had-review-katie-holmes-wows-in-her-meandering-directorial-debut">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Devil and the Deep Blue Sea: Jason Sudeikis sinks into melodrama</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/15/the-devil-and-the-deep-blue-sea-jason-sudeikis-tribeca</link>
      <description><p>The Horrible Bosses star is out of his depth in this mawkish weepie about a depressed architect who strikes up a friendship with a homeless girl</p><p>In <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/11/demolition-review-jake-gyllenhaal-muddled-quirkfest-crashes-emptiness-tiff">Demolition</a>, which recently opened in the US, Jake Gyllenhaal plays a well-off banker who sparks a friendship with a stranger to help cope with his wife’s recent death. The film deservedly tanked with critics – the Guardian’s Benjamin Lee <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/11/demolition-review-jake-gyllenhaal-muddled-quirkfest-crashes-emptiness-tiff">said</a> it “crashes into emptiness”.</p><p>Now comes The Devil and the Deep Blue Sea, another drama about a widower who finds solace in the company of a wayward teenager. As well as its plot being eerily similar to that of Demolition, it’s just as misguided.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/15/the-devil-and-the-deep-blue-sea-jason-sudeikis-tribeca">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The 12 Years a Slave star appears alongside Selma’s David Oyelowo in Disney’s live-action feature set in Uganda and based on a true story. Queen of Katwe is about 8-year-old girl called Phiona Mutesi (Madina Nalwanga<strong>)</strong> who starts out selling corn in a Ugandan village, but discovers her amazing chess abilities. The latest X-Men prequel, directed by Bryan Singer, sees the mutants battle the ur-mutant, the first mutant of them all, who is intent on destroying the world before building it anew</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/x-men-apocalypse-review-marvel-jennifer-lawrence-oscar-isaac">X-Men: Apocalypse review – lots of bangs for your bucks but loopiness is lost</a></li><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2015/dec/11/x-men-apocalypse-trailer-oscar-isaac-sophie-turner-james-mcavoy">X-Men: Apocalypse – five things we learned from the first full trailer</a></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/10/x-men-apocalypse-the-trailer-for-the-new-marvel-prequel-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Tom Hiddleston, the star of new Hank Williams biopic I Saw the Light, meets Henry Barnes in <a href="http://www.macaris.co.uk/">Macari’s guitar shop in London</a> to sing some tunes and swap strumming tips.       <title>Roman Polanski's Macbeth: a clip from the gory 1971 Shakespeare adaptation – video</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/05/roman-polanski-macbeth-clip-gory-1971-shakespeare-video</link>
      <description><p>Roman Polanski’s adaptation of Macbeth, co-scripted by Kenneth Tynan and starring Jon Finch and Francesca Annis, is arguably the most bloodsoaked one ever – made in the aftermath of his wife Sharon Tate’s murder by the Manson ‘family’. In this clip, we see Finch’s Macbeth fight Macduff (Terence Bayler) in the celebrated ‘untimely ripp’d’ climactic scene. The Tragedy of Macbeth (Criterion Collection) is available now on Blu-Ray</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2014/feb/17/martin-shaw-roman-polanski-macbeth-judge-john-deed">Read Judge John Deeds star Martin Shaw’s account of working on the film</a><br></li></ul> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/05/roman-polanski-macbeth-clip-gory-1971-shakespeare-video">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>A clip from the latest John le Carré adaptation, Our Kind of Traitor, which stars Ewan McGregor as an academic out of his depth when a Russian mobster (Stellan Skarsgård) wants to defect to the UK. Homeland’s Damian Lewis features as the slippery government mandarin who oversees the operation, seen in this clip conducting an undercover snoop at Arsenal’s Emirates stadium.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/04/seth-rogen-bad-neighbours-sorority-rising-chloe-grace-moretz-video-interview</link>
      <description><p>Seth Rogen, the co-writer and star of the sequel to Bad Neighbours, joins star Chloë Grace Moretz to discuss re-evaluating previous films through a feminist lens, why college culture in the US is inherently sexist, how Americans tend to like exclusive clubs – and whether there is anything worse than watching people pretend to party</p><p>• Bad Neighbours opens in the UK on 6 May, in Australia on 10 May and in the US – where it’s known as Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising – on 20 May</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/may/04/seth-rogen-bad-neighbours-sorority-rising-chloe-grace-moretz-video-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Is Ghostbusters the unfortunate victim of Hollywood hitting peak reboot?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/ghostbusters-reboot-hollywood-paul-feig-bill-murray</link>
      <description><p>It’s hard to believe geek culture ‘sexism’ is responsible for all the bad buzz aimed at Paul Feig’s female-fronted remake. Now we need Bill Murray to save the day</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/03/melissa-mccarthy-admits-she-found-ghostbusters-trailer-very-confusing">Melissa McCarthy admits she found Ghostbusters trailer 'very confusing'</a> </p><p>You might remember a little 2010 superhero film titled Kick-Ass. Long before Deadpool flew the flag for comic book irreverence on the big screen, there was this swear-y, ultra-violent high school movie about what might happen if geek culture truly ate itself, and average Joes began to walk the street at night dressed as real-life superheroes. The junior Watchmen, if you like.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/ghostbusters-reboot-hollywood-paul-feig-bill-murray">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>John Cho, of Harold &amp; Kumar and ‘Milf’ fame, has become the unwitting face of a campaign against Hollywood ‘whitewashing’. Digital strategist William Yu, 25, has used Photoshop and the hashtag #StarringJohnCho to place the actor over white faces in a series of movie posters.     <item>
      <title>Carol left me cold – but a new movie has restored my faith in lesbian cinema | Julie Bindel</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/09/carol-left-me-cold-but-a-new-movie-has-restored-my-faith-in-lesbian-cinema</link>
      <description><p>All About E is a genuine love story which manages to captivate without being tragic or overly sentimental</p><p> All About E may be a story of lesbian treachery and heartbreak, but it is far from depressing. Rather, it is a road movie that incapsulates the intoxicating pleasures of the transgressing tradition, as well as the endless possibilities and ways of realising the authentic self. </p><p>The plot that holds this good looking film together is as thin as a supermodel, simply adding a little external drama to the central theme: that of a story of true love and desire between young lesbians. Set in Australia, with stunning cinematography showing off the outback landscape, it features plenty of gentle laughs and surprisingly little schmaltz.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/09/carol-left-me-cold-but-a-new-movie-has-restored-my-faith-in-lesbian-cinema">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why working-class actors are a disappearing breed</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/08/working-class-actors-disappearing-britain-class-privilege-access-posh</link>
      <description>Once we had gritty TV dramas such as Boys from the Blackstuff; now we have glossy thrillers with public school-educated stars. How did British screens become dominated by the privileged few? And does it matter?<p>The BBC’s recent hit drama <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/the-night-manager"><em>The Night Manager</em></a>, a thriller about a spy who infiltrates an arms dealer’s network, is the sort of show that’s sometimes described as “aspirational” – not because most people aspire to hang out with the kind of foreign despots liable to gas their own people, but because it’s the sort of world that features private jets and five-star hotels and characters called things like “Dickie Onslow Roper” and “Lord Langbourne” and the kind of long-necked women who drape themselves languidly over business tycoons’ arms.</p><p>It is, to use another piece of shorthand, posh; a world of money and privilege – and apart from two overworked civil servants trying to bring them to heel from a dingy London office, one of whom is Olivia Colman, the BBC’s resident everywoman – almost the entire cast comes from what used to be called the “officer class”. So it’s not exactly a surprise when, just after the final episode is broadcast, the <em>Guardian </em>runs a story about <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/education/shortcuts/2016/mar/28/dragon-school-tom-hiddleston-tom-hollander-hugh-laurie-night-manager">where the three male leads went to school</a>. Because for the past 18 months or so, the papers have been full of stories about how increasingly rarefied acting is becoming. How difficult it is for anyone from any normal background to break into it. How some of the great actors of the past 30 years simply wouldn’t make it today.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/08/working-class-actors-disappearing-britain-class-privilege-access-posh">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Captain America: Civil War is better than Batman v Superman</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/07/captain-america-civil-war-better-than-batman-v-superman</link>
      <description><p>The characters are more than just flimsy action figures and the moral quandaries are absorbing – this is a superior superhero smackdown</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/captain-america-civil-war-review-an-aspartame-rush">Captain America: Civil War</a>, the latest billion-dollar sensory assault from the mighty Marvel Studios, arrived in North American theaters last Thursday. While I would normally present to you an all-you-can-hate buffet of reasons to loathe this film, I simply cannot. It’s quite good. Great, even. I will stop short of declaring it a new benchmark for human creativity, but I will gladly admit I had fun in my seat during most of the runtime.</p><p><a href="http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/captain_america_civil_war/">Civil War sits at 91% on Rotten Tomatoes as of press time</a>, which is 63 percentage points higher than the recent release from Marvel’s mortal enemies at DC Comics, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/man-of-steel-2">Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice</a> – a movie I hated with the passion of a thousand red Kryptonian suns. Civil War was very, very enjoyable, but was it that much better than Batman v Superman? Let’s find out.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/07/captain-america-civil-war-better-than-batman-v-superman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Han Solo: A Star Wars Story must balance nostalgia with new adventures</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/han-solo-a-star-wars-story-alden-ehrenreich-disney</link>
      <description><p>Fans hoping to see Han meeting Chewbacca, winning the Millennium Falcon and completing the Kessel Run should be careful what they wish for in spin-off</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/alden-ehrenreich-han-solo-star-wars-harrison-ford">Alden Ehrenreich confirmed to play young Han Solo in Star Wars spin-off</a> </p><p>The legend goes that Harrison Ford only got the chance to audition for the part of sardonic space smuggler Han Solo in 1977’s Star Wars because he happened to be working as a handyman at Elstree Studios during George Lucas’s shoot. The truth, as ever, is somewhat more complex: Ford did work as a carpenter to support himself between jobs before winning his breakthrough role, but he was actually <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TaM9qCpphIw">on set as a line reader for Lucas</a> when the director realised his Solo stand-in really ought to be playing the role for real. And Ford had already appeared in the young film-maker’s American Graffiti three years previously (in a small role as a neighbourhood bully) so he was hardly a Hollywood ingenue.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/han-solo-a-star-wars-story-alden-ehrenreich-disney">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Better on Netflix: which failed sci-fi and fantasy epics deserve to stream again?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/netflix-amazon-sci-fi-streaming-reboots-dredd-hulk</link>
      <description><p>Dredd star Karl Urban says the Mega City One lawman could return via the magic of streaming. Which other box-office bombs are ripe for resurrection?</p><p>Not so long ago, if you wanted to see a revival of that much-loved cult classic adored by fans but scorned by the masses, your best bet was most likely some kind of crowdfunding campaign. These days, streaming sites such as Netflix are playing Dr Frankenstein with everything from Chinese martial arts epics (the utterly appalling <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/26/crouching-tiger-hidden-dragon-sword-of-destiny-sequel-review">Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny</a>) to cheesy noughties teen comedies (recent miniseries Wet Hot American Summer: First Day of Camp, based on the 2001 indie favourite). So which other movies could do with a jolt of streaming-fuelled defibrillation? Come on Netflix (or Amazon), resurrect these little gems for us and we’ll hand over our monthly subscription fees with a toe-tapping jig and a smile as wide as the Ganges.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/netflix-amazon-sci-fi-streaming-reboots-dredd-hulk">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Foxes at the box office – who would star in Leicester City: the Movie?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/03/leicester-city-the-movie-star-hanks-elba-hiddleston</link>
      <description><p>Tom Hanks tinkering with teamsheets as Ranieri, Idris Elba barking orders as captain Morgan, and Tom Hiddleston smashing in the goals … a surefire lineup to get them queuing at the turnstiles</p><p>Film producers like nothing more than a chest-burstingly uplifting, against-the-odds, underdog-come-good, overcoming-adversity story, and Leicester City’s tilt at the Premier League title is about as chestburstingly uplifting as they come. So just as football journalists have been sharpening their pens and documentary-makers loading up their editing suites over the past few weeks as the Foxes have been closing in on the championship, film production executives will have begun the unseemly jostle to get Leicester City: The Movie in the works. </p><p>But how to go about it? The first issue is where to pitch it. Notoriously, most films about football – about British football, at least – have been pretty bad: hamstrung between the need to appeal to the widest possible only-vaguely-interested audience (ie, the US) while not alienating the rabid, intensely knowledgeable home support. The poorly received Goal! trilogy fell between every stool possible. (One of its writers, Adrian Butchart, is <a href="http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/jamie-vardy-movie-film-leicester-7697298">the man talking up a potential Jamie Vardy movie</a> – but this, like much else in the film world, is a case of attempting to hype a film into existence.) The Damned United did a good job in dramatising Brian Clough’s relationship with Peter Taylor, but the actual football left a bit to be desired. Mike Bassett: England Manager mined Graham Taylor’s discomfiture for laughs, but Leicester City: The Movie won’t be a vehicle for satire.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/03/leicester-city-the-movie-star-hanks-elba-hiddleston">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I hate it but it's true: Marvel's big-screen superheroes chomp up the competition</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/03/marvels-superheroes-big-screen-showdown-dc-comics-captain-america-civil-war-batman-v-superman</link>
      <description><p>Even a DC Comics fan like me has to admit that with Captain America, Marvel’s big-screen presence has muscled out the competition</p><p>If you saw the cache of superhero comics I have, you’d notice two things: first, that this extended adolescent obsession is getting out of hand; second, my stash is two-to-one in favour of DC Comics over Marvel. I prefer the adventures of Superman, Green Lantern, Wonder Woman, Aquaman and the Flash (not to mention Blue Beetle, Zatanna, Power Girl, Harley Quinn, Black Canary and Captain Atom) to those of most of the Marvel gang (except Spider-Man, Thor and the Fantastic Four). Still, we have reached a point where it must be put it in the most blunt, playground-ready of terms: Marvel films can beat up DC films.</p><p>A measure of who’s got bigger muscles isn’t out of line. Consider the titles of the two most recent films: <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/22/batman-v-superman-dawn-of-justice-review-ben-affleck-henry-cavill">Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/captain-america-civil-war-review-an-aspartame-rush">Captain America: Civil War</a>. They’re remarkable in their similarities, so much so that even those uninterested in funny-book debate are likely to make comparisons. And anyone who came away from the brawl thinking DC were the champs must have received a meta-human blow to the head.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/03/marvels-superheroes-big-screen-showdown-dc-comics-captain-america-civil-war-batman-v-superman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Celebrity cameos: has the joke worn thin?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/30/celebrity-cameos-absolutely-fabulous-has-the-joke-worn-thin</link>
      <description><p>From the new Absolutely Fabulous movie to Zoolander 2, Ryan Gilbey reflects on what separates the unforgettable star turns from the excruciating B-list cash-ins</p><p>In her BBC sitcom Absolutely Fabulous, Jennifer Saunders was never slow to rope in famous chums to add an in-jokey authenticity to her portrait of the fag-end of the high life. <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dj3ZWhlmexw">The forthcoming movie version promises to be a similar model of celebrity democracy</a>, with a cast that runs from A-list to Z-list. Where else would you find Kate Moss rubbing shoulders with Judith Chalmers? Or Alexa Chung and Daisy Lowe cosying up to Christopher Biggins? If a bomb had dropped on set, it would have been goodbye to Hello! magazine. Heat might have frozen over.</p><p>No big-budget comedy is complete until the producers have milked their contacts book dry for star cameos. Overkill was part of the gag in the third Austin Powers film (Tom Cruise, Gwyneth Paltrow, Kevin Spacey, Steven Spielberg) and the second Anchorman (Will Smith, Marion Cotillard, Liam Neeson, Kanye West). But this trick had worn thin by the time of Zoolander 2. A devilishly funny opening sequence shows Justin Bieber being gunned down; he reaches for his phone, takes a selfie, selects a filter, posts it on Instagram – and then expires. The remainder of the film suggested that its makers had inserted a star cameo whenever inspiration was flagging. Unfortunately, Anna Wintour and Susan Boyle proved to be no substitute for decent jokes.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/30/celebrity-cameos-absolutely-fabulous-has-the-joke-worn-thin">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Captain America: Civil War – discuss the film with spoilers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/captain-america-civil-war-discuss-the-film-with-spoilers-marvel</link>
      <description><p>It’s been hailed for its slick universe-building, searing badinage and subtle villain. But what did you make of Marvel’s latest superhero megaflick?</p><p>Captain America: Civil War is officially the best-reviewed superhero movie of all time, with a staggering 98% “fresh” rating on the review aggregator Rotten Tomatoes. That’s ahead of Christopher Nolan’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2008/jul/25/actionandadventure1">The Dark Knight</a> (94%), and even better than Pixar’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/nov/19/the-incredibles-film-review">The Incredibles</a> (97%). But is the Russo brothers’ film really the European white truffle of comic-book movies, or just cleverly crafted celluloid candy floss, sweet to the taste but utterly lacking in nutrition? Here are some talking points you might want to consider.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/captain-america-civil-war-discuss-the-film-with-spoilers-marvel">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>First World Problems: The Movie – can audiences ever pity wealthy, attractive heroes?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/first-world-problems-the-movie-can-audiences-ever-pity-wealthy-attractive-heroes</link>
      <description><p>Knight of Cups is just the latest film out to make us feel sorry for glamorous people cursed with success</p><p>‘Where did I go wrong,” mopes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/christianbale" title="">Christian Bale</a>’s character in the latest <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/terrence-malick" title="">Terrence Malick</a> film, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/knight-of-cups" title="">Knight of Cups</a>. It’s a question he broods over for two beautifully shot hours. But to the viewer, the answer seems simple: you didn’t go wrong! Your life is fantastic. You look like Christian Bale. You don’t have any health issues or addictions. You’re an in-demand screenwriter, and yet, instead of doing any work, you spend your days wandering around decadent Hollywood house parties and strolling along the beach in an Armani suit. True, you’ve broken up with your wife (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/cate-blanchett" title="">Cate Blanchett</a>), but your subsequent girlfriends are played by <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/natalie-portman" title="">Natalie Portman</a>, Imogen Poots, Freida Pinto, Teresa Palmer and Isabel Lucas – and that’s not including all the nubile models who keep frolicking in your hotel room. A film that could easily be retitled First World Problems: The Movie, Knight of Cups is laden with voice-over assuring us that Rick is racked with regret. But anyone who watched it with the sound turned down might assume that it was an unusually arty episode of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/entourage" title="">Entourage</a>. Are we supposed to take this existential fretting seriously?</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/feb/08/knight-of-cups-review-film-terrence-malick-christian-bale">Knight of Cups review: Malick's back! With the least interesting spiritual crisis in history</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/first-world-problems-the-movie-can-audiences-ever-pity-wealthy-attractive-heroes">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How superhero movies embraced wild west frontier libertarianism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/how-superhero-movies-embraced-wild-west-frontier-libertarianism</link>
      <description><p>Captain America: Civil War isn’t the only comic-book movie to champion the strong individual over unreliable authority figures when it comes to sorting good from bad. The tactic worked well before – in westerns </p><p>Link Appleyard might be the archetypal cowardly wild west lawman. John Ford’s classic 1962 western <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EVXuo2WiU_I">The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance</a> presents the gutless town marshal, played by Andy Devine, as a legacy of the cracks in the system that require strong men like John Wayne’s steely Tom Doniphon to deliver true justice in a time of chaos. When Lee Marvin’s bestial Valance rolls into town to bully greenhorn lawyer James Stewart, it is not the bumbling Appleyard who steps up to help him. Instead, it is the indestructible Wayne, a superhero in everything but name and outfit, who delivers the bullet that saves Stewart’s bacon.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/captain-america-civil-war-clash-of-philosophies">Captain America: Civil War – conflicted heroes and a clash of philosophies</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/how-superhero-movies-embraced-wild-west-frontier-libertarianism">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Maleficent 2: the worst example of Angelina's Jolieland syndrome</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/26/maleficent-2-angelina-jolie-syndrome-disney</link>
      <description><p>She may have virtually retired from on-camera duties, but the tour-de-force star is surely too spectacular to end her career with a lazy fantasy prequel</p><p>Kevin Smith <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8LhcParuzpc">has a wonderful story to tell about the time he nearly made a documentary with Prince</a>. It’s a fascinating insight into the minds of incredibly successful people who have been in the spotlight for longer than they can remember. </p><p>After a week spent in the company of the purple one, during which the genius behind Purple Rain and Raspberry Beret asked him to film a series of fan encounters at his Paisley Park estate in Minneapolis, the Clerks director found himself at the end of his tether after being asked to personally relay Prince’s eccentric message of Jesus to the assembled throngs, despite his own complete lack of religious belief. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/26/maleficent-2-angelina-jolie-syndrome-disney">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sorry, Ridley Scott: Sigourney Weaver is the only true Alien scream queen</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/ridley-scott-sigourney-weaver-alien-covenant-prometheus-sequel</link>
      <description><p>It’s a shame the veteran British film-maker has blocked Neill Blomkamp’s plan to resurrect Ellen Ripley (again) in favour of a tedious-sounding Prometheus sequel</p><p>Let me paint for you, just for a moment, a nightmarish scenario to compare with the hellish visions seen in HR Giger’s <a href="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/d/db/H.R._Giger_-_Necronom_IV.jpg">Necronom IV</a>, the Swiss surrealist painter’s inspiration for his later work on the hideous xenomorphs in 1979’s Alien. </p><p>Imagine for a moment that George Lucas, not long after Disney hired JJ Abrams to direct the first new Star Wars movie in more than a decade – perhaps even after the release of that <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OMOVFvcNfvE">first teaser trailer for The Force Awakens</a>, which sent everyone into apoplexies of expectation – found something in the small print that allowed him to change his mind about handing over the long-running space saga to a bunch of newbies.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/ridley-scott-sigourney-weaver-alien-covenant-prometheus-sequel">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Captain America: Civil War shows why superheroes shouldn’t team up</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/25/captain-america-civil-war-shows-why-superheroes-shouldnt-team-up</link>
      <description><p>Superman and Batman can only seem to summon their superpowers en masse. But I’ll take a Bourne or Bond over a pack of superheroes any day</p><p>Superheroes used to be loners. They were isolated by the exclusivity of their superpowers, the singularity of their origins, the particularity of their neuroses and the eccentricity of their garb. </p><p>The very earliest of the big-screen superheroes, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xNKMbxLcuac">Captain Marvel</a> (1941) and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G6Zo_BaxTsk  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G6Zo_BaxTs">Batman</a> (1943), were marked out by their apartness. When the genre really took off, in1978, it found Christopher Reeve’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/pictures/image/0,8545,-10205036390,00.html">Superman</a> grappling with his solitude. If Michael Keaton’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/News_Story/Critic_Review/Guardian_review/0,,558607,00.html">Batman</a> (1989) was hardly companionable, Christian Bale’s was even less so. Through the 1990s and the 2000s, most of their burgeoning array of peers managed to cut the mustard by themselves.<strong> </strong></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/25/captain-america-civil-war-shows-why-superheroes-shouldnt-team-up">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Uncomfortable viewing: the seven-hour trailer for a 30-day film</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/shortcuts/2016/apr/24/uncomfortable-viewing-the-seven-hour-trailer-for-a-30-day-film</link>
      <description><p>Swedish director Anders Weberg has taken ‘slow cinema’ to a new level with the preview for his latest film, Ambiancé. Can’t get enough of this snippet? The next preview will be 72 hours long …<br></p><p>OK, here is the elevator pitch: We are on a beach. The sea just visible on the right-hand side of the frame. Low camera angle. Black and white. Ghostly flickers superimposed over the main image. A&nbsp;synthesiser chord on the soundtrack. Nothing happens for about 12 minutes. Then we see a&nbsp;black dot and a white dot at the far end of the beach. They are people dressed in robes, walking towards us. In slow motion. By about 20 minutes in, they are near&nbsp;us, gathering debris on the beach. Wait – we are at the ground floor already? But we have only just got started!</p><p>There are another seven hours to go, in fact. Though not a lot else happens, to be honest. The black-robed person paints some stuff white; the white-robed person paints some stuff black. Roughly an hour and 15 minutes in, they dramatically exit the scene. But 10 minutes later they reappear, and unfurl a banner. On it is painted … Uh-uh. No spoilers here. But the good news is, this is&nbsp;just the trailer. The actual <a href="http://www.thelongestfilm.com/" title="">film</a>, titled Ambiancé, is 720 hours long. You ain’t seen nothing yet – almost literally.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/shortcuts/2016/apr/24/uncomfortable-viewing-the-seven-hour-trailer-for-a-30-day-film">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Five things we learned from the debut trailer for Jason Bourne</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/jason-bourne-trailer-things-we-learned-matt-damon-julia-stiles</link>
      <description><p>Matt Damon’s up against a post-Snowden CIA, Julia Stiles knows where the next high-octane set piece is and Vincent Cassel is killing in the name of state secrets</p><p>It’s been nine years since the last proper Bourne movie (sorry Jeremy Renner, but <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2012/aug/09/the-bourne-legacy-review">The Bourne Legacy</a> doesn’t really count). In that time, we’ve discovered the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/the-nsa-files">government really is watching you</a>, and that getting on the wrong side of them really will <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2015/dec/24/chelsea-manning-christmas-prison-whistleblower-wikileaks">result in the harshest treatment imaginable</a>. Comic book movies such as the Captain America series may have taken the spy agency-gone-rogue trope and turned it into a template for the modern superhero epic, but Matt Damon’s returning amnesiac super-soldier somehow still doesn’t seem like nearly such a fanciful creation as he used to. Now that the first trailer for Jason Bourne has landed, what data can we glean from our debut opportunity to put Paul Greengrass’s movie under surveillance?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/jason-bourne-trailer-things-we-learned-matt-damon-julia-stiles">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>We've reached peak superhero. So which ones should we cull?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/which-big-screen-superheroes-should-be-culled-marvel-warner-bros-film</link>
      <description><p>With new Captain America and X-Men episodes set to follow Batman v Superman and Deadpool into crowded multiplexes, which costumed crime fighters deserve to be put out to pasture?</p><p>The history of comic books is littered with the corpses of costumed titans who never quite made it, from <a href="http://comicvine.gamespot.com/fatman-the-human-flying-saucer/4005-67994/">Fatman the Human Flying Saucer</a> to Jack Kirby’s space opera hero <a href="http://comicvine.gamespot.com/captain-victory-and-the-galactic-rangers/4050-3101/">Captain Victory and the Galactic Rangers</a>. Some survived for years to entertain golden- and silver-age audiences, while others were sent to superhero purgatory after a single issue. Jon Morris’s excellent book <a draggable="true" href="http://www.amazon.com/The-League-Regrettable-Superheroes-Half-Baked/dp/1594747636">The League of Regrettable Superheroes</a> has more examples of colourful characters who fell by the wayside, from Madame Fatal (the world’s first ever cross-dressing granny superhero) to Bozo the Iron Man (a remote-controlled, jive-talking robot crimefighter), long before Marvel Studios took over the multiplexes.<br tabindex="-1"></p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/captain-america-civil-war-clash-of-philosophies">Captain America: Civil War – conflicted heroes and a clash of philosophies</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/which-big-screen-superheroes-should-be-culled-marvel-warner-bros-film">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jane Got a Gun – but most women in westerns still don't</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/jane-got-a-gun-most-women-in-westerns-dont</link>
      <description><p>From Belle Starr to Calamity Jane, women rarely wield a gun with gusto in the wild west. Will Hollywood ever do justice to female sharp-shooters?</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/31/jane-got-a-gun-review-big-nat-no-cattle-as-portman-western-fires-blanks">Jane Got a Gun</a> is set somewhere in New Mexico Territory in 1871. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/natalie-portman">Natalie Portman</a>’s grievously wounded husband makes it back to their homestead and warns her there’s a posse of villains on his heels. The posse takes ages to get there, though, so she has time to park her small daughter with a neighbour, then go and ask her resentful ex-boyfriend (<a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/joel-edgerton">Joel Edgerton</a>) for help, and take shooting lessons in preparation for the showdown. Edgerton has never forgiven her for having ditched him while he was in the army, but since he lives about 10 minutes away, it’s a wonder that it’s only now, after seven years, that she lets him know what really went down while he was away. And it turns out to be a full complement of Awful Things That Can Happen to a Woman in the Wild West.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/jane-got-a-gun-most-women-in-westerns-dont">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Captain America: Civil War – conflicted heroes and a clash of philosophies</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/captain-america-civil-war-clash-of-philosophies</link>
      <description><p>Iron Man thinks like John Stuart Mill, while Captain America is a Kantian – but the real insight comes from the fact that each sees the other side’s argument</p><p>These days the world feels precarious. It seems we face new threats every day from extremist forces both domestic and international. At the same time, we’re developing new ways to detect and predict these threats, using advanced surveillance and drone technology to enhance our safety and security – but at what cost to our liberties and freedoms? Must we choose which of these we value most and give up on the other?<br></p><p>Some of our favorite superheroes can help us think about this timeless conflict. In Marvel Comics’s Civil War storyline, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/captain-america-civil-war-tipped-biggest-us-opening-2016">the latest movie version of which is released on 6 May</a>, Captain America, Iron Man and the rest of the Marvel heroes face off over the same issues of liberty and security that we face in the real world every day, and they find the answers neither easy nor simple. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/captain-america-civil-war-clash-of-philosophies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why Dheepan's take on immigration isn't helpful</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/20/dheepan-immigration-depiction-selective-jacques-audiard-multiracial-france</link>
      <description><p>Jacques Audiard’s depiction of Sri Lankans faking family ties to escape war is powerful, but highly selective in both the challenges the outcasts meet and its toxic depiction of France’s multiracial suburbs</p><p>There’s a touching scene in Jacques Audiard’s film <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/video/2016/apr/07/dheepan-star-antonythasan-jesuthasan-video-interview">Dheepan</a> in which Yalini tells her husband Dheepan that the reason he doesn’t find French jokes funny isn’t because French jokes aren’t funny or that he doesn’t understand the language, but because he has no sense of humour in any language. The scene is terrific because it marks a moment of understanding between the two characters, briskly paints the differences between them, and riffs on the theme of language, which sets them so at odds with their surroundings. Yalini isn’t really Dheepan’s wife: they pretended to be married in order to escape Sri Lanka for the Parisian suburb they now find themselves in, with an equally unrelated girl, Illayaal, pretending to be their nine-year-old daughter.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/07/dheepan-review-jacques-audiard-palme-d-or">Dheepan review – a crime drama packed with epiphanic grandeur</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/20/dheepan-immigration-depiction-selective-jacques-audiard-multiracial-france">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/dheepan">Dheepan</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/jacques-audiard">Jacques Audiard</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/migration">Migration</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/srilanka">Sri Lanka</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/france">France</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/south-and-central-asia">South and Central Asia</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/world">World news</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/world/europe-news">Europe</category>

    <item>
      <title>Why Max Landis is wrong about Scarlett Johansson's 'whitewashed' Ghost in the Shell remake</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/scarlett-johansson-ghost-in-the-shell-max-landis</link>
      <description><p>Box office failure for Pan, Gods of Egypt, The Lone Ranger and Aloha really should have taught Hollywood that race-swapping is never the answer – no matter how big the star involved</p><p>Are we supposed to have sympathy for the Hollywood screenwriter Max Landis after he was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/max-landis-denies-defence-of-scarlett-johansson-ghost-in-the-shell">accused of defending Scarlett Johansson’s casting in the upcoming live-action remake of Ghost in the Shell</a>? Well, perhaps a little bit. Landis, with his impromptu YouTube “vlog”, was merely trying to explain the twisted thinking that goes on when studios make the decision to “whitewash” famous roles, the clink-clank of Hollywood machinery that over the past year has given us Johansson as Major Kusanagi, Scotsman Gerard Butler as the Egyptian deity Set (in Alex Proyas’ Gods of Egypt) and Rooney Mara as Native American princess Tiger Lily (in Joe Wright’s Pan). </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/18/scarlett-johansson-ghost-in-the-shell-max-landis">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>From Titanic to The Revenant: why don’t movie stars learn from their characters?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/14/from-titanic-to-the-revenant-why-dont-movie-stars-learn-from-their-characters</link>
      <description><p>Leonardo DiCaprio’s experience at the end of Titanic helped him survive The Revenant. The Martian enabled Matt Damon to do what he couldn’t in Interstellar. Look and learn, Domhnall Gleeson</p><p>In the famous farewell scene toward the end of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/titanic">Titanic</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/leonardodicaprio">Leonardo DiCaprio</a> treads water while speaking to <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/katewinslet">Kate Winslet</a>, desperately trying to stave off the effects of hypothermia. He lasts about eight minutes, which is probably a record for this sort of thing, as the glacial waters of the north Atlantic in April would normally be expected to kill off even the hardiest soul within three. But eventually the gallant DiCaprio succumbs, and drifts off to his watery sepulchre.</p><p>In last year’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/the-revenant">The Revenant</a>, DiCaprio had a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/24/hey-academy-look-revenant-leonardo-dicaprio-greatest-hits">similar bone-chilling experience</a>, when he was forced to plunge into an icy river in the middle of winter to escape from vengeful Native Americans. The water must have been positively frigid, and he would have needed to stay submerged for a reasonably long time to escape his pursuers. Given that he had recently been ripped to shreds not once, but twice, by an ill-tempered grizzly bear, you’d assume that DiCaprio would have gone down for the count pretty quickly. Yet, this time around, defying all known physiological and hibernal-aquatic rules, DiCaprio survived the gruelling ordeal. How? Why?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/14/from-titanic-to-the-revenant-why-dont-movie-stars-learn-from-their-characters">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/13/london-has-fallen-can-city-siege-movies-survive-the-age-of-terror</link>
      <description><p>Watching landmarks being blown up used to be thrilling. But can we enjoy films like Bastille Day, Made in France and London Has Fallen in the same way after the Paris and Brussels attacks? </p><p>In <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/02/london-has-fallen-review-gerard-butler-bromance-brews-as-big-ben-blows">London Has Fallen</a>, the Italian prime minister is on the roof of one of Westminster Abbey’s towers, canoodling with a woman 30 years his junior. This Berlucsconian cliche is ostensibly in town, along with other world leaders, for the funeral of his British counterpart.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/06/london-has-fallen-review-laughable-action">London Has Fallen review – Team America without the jokes</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/13/london-has-fallen-can-city-siege-movies-survive-the-age-of-terror">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Why, in 2016, are women still (mostly) silent film stars?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/women-film-speaking-roles-2016-study-hollywood</link>
      <description><p>Study lays bare the fact that women are given far less dialogue than male actors – because it’s men who still get to tell the stories that form our cultural narratives</p><p>It’s rare to have proof that the less sexually desirable a woman is perceived to be, the less anyone cares what she has to say. And yet, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/women-less-dialogue-hollywood-films-older-study-survey">Polygraph’s study of who is granted on-screen dialogue in more than 1,000 movies</a> does exactly that: the percentage of dialogue allotted female characters waned after actors hit 31, dropped precipitously after they hit 42 and all but disappeared when they hit 65.</p><p>But when in 2014 <a href="http://variety.com/2015/film/news/women-hollywood-inequality-directors-behind-the-camera-1201626691/">80% of films had no women credited as writers</a>, perhaps it’s to be expected that women overall had fewer lines and that the on-screen women the mostly male writers and directors thought audiences would like to hear are the youngest. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/women-film-speaking-roles-2016-study-hollywood">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/gary-oldman-spotlight-oscar-best-picture</link>
      <description><p>The actor recently admitted to being befuddled by Spotlight’s triumph at the Oscars – but his critique is old-fashioned with a whiff of sour grapes</p><p>Gary Oldman is a cinema-goer’s dream and a publicist’s nightmare. </p><p>The revered actor, whose performances as the titular demon in Bram Stoker’s Dracula and as Sex Pistols bassist Sid Vicious in Sid and Nancy stand out because of their singular strangeness, is still among the most exciting actors working today.     <item>
      <title>Harder, better, faster, stronger? Why comic book movies are growing longer</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/05/why-comic-book-movies-are-growing-longer-suicide-squad</link>
      <description><p>From stuffing in jokes to extended character explainers, new comic book movies are taking up more and more of our time. And I’m not sure it’s worth it</p><p>When news broke that Suicide Squad, David Ayer’s upcoming DC mega-villain mashup, was <a href="http://birthmoviesdeath.com/2016/03/31/suicide-squad-reshoots-bode-well-for-the-dc-movieverse">heading back for reshoots in March</a>, months after wrapping principal photography, there was widespread panic among fans. Josh Trank’s doomed <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/aug/05/fantastic-four-review-marvel-superhero-dawdling">Fantastic Four reboot</a> underwent the same process – and not even that could save it from being an unmitigated disaster. </p><p>Stung by immediate negative feedback from folk concerned Suicide Squad was in similar trouble (rumours alleged Warner Bros ordered the reshoots to add more Deadpool-style zingers), Ayer responded on Twitter. His reasoning for the additional footage: the studio, liking what it saw, gave him carte blanche to shoot more – and so naturally, he ran with the opportunity.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/may/05/why-comic-book-movies-are-growing-longer-suicide-squad">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Show me the motivation! Why Jerry Maguire's full-length mission statement is for superfans only</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/28/jerry-maguire-cameron-crowe-mission-statement-tom-cruise</link>
      <description><p>On the 20th anniversary of the film starring Tom Cruise, the director publishes the exhaustive 5,000-word mission statement he wrote for his crisis-hit sports agent</p><p>Jerry Maguire’s mission statement? For those who have not seen the film in a while, the memory of that could be a little sketchy. Surely Jerry’s mission statement is the movie’s own legendary mission statement. And in fact Hollywood’s mission statement, summarised by the four brash words that sports agent Tom Cruise is forced to shout by his mercurial, recalcitrant client, the football star played by Cuba Gooding Jr. Show me the money!</p><p>Don’t bullshit me with the earnings I could possibly earn in the future, make it happen right now, or I move to another agent … Maybe Cameron Crowe, the writer-director of Jerry Maguire once said it to his own agent. Or maybe his agent said it to him, or felt like saying it – I need my client to be valuable, lucrative and worthwhile, if I’m going to put in all this work in return for 15% down the line: I need him to show me how well his last movie is doing right at this very moment. And Hollywood needs everyone to show the money, show the profits, and put the dollars up on screen.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/28/jerry-maguire-cameron-crowe-mission-statement-tom-cruise">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The Jungle Book remains top of the tree at UK box office</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/26/the-jungle-book-uk-box-office-eye-in-the-sky</link>
      <description><p>Disney’s live-action remake slips just 18% after its stunning opening week, as drone thriller Eye in the Sky looks on in second spot</p><p>Delivering the strongest hold of any film in the UK box-office top 10, The Jungle Book declined only 18% from its stunning opening frame, with second-weekend takings of £8.10m and a 10-day total of £21.66m. Anyway you look at it, £8m is a mighty number for a film’s second week. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/22/batman-v-superman-dawn-of-justice-review-ben-affleck-henry-cavill">Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice</a>, which had a significantly bigger debut than The Jungle Book, delivered just £4.66m on its second weekend. Deadpool, which has so far managed a powerful £37.9m, took £5.69m. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/26/the-jungle-book-uk-box-office-eye-in-the-sky">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Café Society trailer: first look at Woody's latest suggests sparky Coens-ish satire</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/22/cafe-society-woody-allen-trailer-first-look-jesse-eisenberg</link>
      <description><p>Jesse Eisenberg makes another bid to be the perfect Woody Allen substitute in LA-set, Cannes-bound comedy also starring Kristen Stewart and Steve Carell</p><p>Many actors, over the years, have assumed a lesser or great quantity of Woody-isms standing in for him on screen. Some have been no-brainer good fits (Larry David, Owen Wilson) and less easy matches (Kenneth Branagh, Will Ferrell). But it is perhaps Jesse Eisenberg who shows the most promise as a true spiritual soulmate, from his brief appearance in the moderate To Rome With Love. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/audio/2016/apr/22/robert-downey-jr-is-back-for-sherlock-3-and-spider-man-and-bastille-day-reviewed-the-dailies-film-podcast">Robert Downey Jr is back for Sherlock 3 and Spider-Man, and Bastille Day reviewed&nbsp;– the Dailies film podcast</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/22/cafe-society-woody-allen-trailer-first-look-jesse-eisenberg">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How Louder than Bombs dares to discuss some of our stickiest relationships | David Thomson</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/21/why-louder-than-bombs-dares-to-discuss-stickiest-family-relationships</link>
      <description><p>Most families have tensions, but the fractured one in Joachim Trier’s drama tests the limits of how far blood ties can stretch without losing connection altogether</p><p>A young father, Jonah, looks at his newborn baby. Fingers over 20 years apart in age come together. His wife, Amy, watches him, more than she looks at their child. Has she pleased him with this baby? Why is it that quite soon Jonah will tell his brother he’s sure Amy is going to leave him? There is an uncanny uneasiness in this happy moment. The fraught tone of an unusual film is being offered.<br></p><p> Amy is hungry. Jonah says he will search in the night-time hospital for food. As he enquires, he finds a woman he has loved before, Erin. She is at the hospital for her mother who isn’t even 60 yet. Jonah wants to comfort her tears. She wonders what he is doing in the hospital. “My wife,” he begins, but he doesn’t tell her his whole story. She thinks the wife is ill and they are in each other’s arms in consolation. But their feeling is more than that: the new father will become Erin’s lover again. At the close of this film, his younger brother, Conrad (the apparent problem child), will tell their father: “Jonah – he’s not doing so well.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/21/why-louder-than-bombs-dares-to-discuss-stickiest-family-relationships">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Macaulay Culkin: 'Aladdin is a passion project'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/macaulay-culkmacaulay-culkin-aladdin-arabian-nights-adam-green</link>
      <description><p>The former star of Home Alone stars in a surreal stoner version of the Arabian Nights tale masterminded by his musician friend Adam Green</p><p>Anyone raised on the Disney version of Aladdin may be surprised by Adam Green’s take on the Arabian Nights tale. Green, who rose to fame as one half of the early 2000s indie-rock band <a href="http://www.moldypeaches.com/">the Moldy Peaches</a>, has created an acid-dipped retelling of Aladdin set in a papier-mache world, ruled by a sultan played by painter <a href="http://www.francescoclemente.net/">Francesco Clemente</a>, with a princess that Green describes as “kind of like a Kardashian”, and a magic lamp outfitted with a 3D printer.</p><p>Green stars as the titular character, alongside <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/27/antibirth-review-film-sundance-2016-natasha-lyonne-cronenberg-dude">Natasha Lyonne</a>, former child star <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2013/dec/10/macaulay-culkin-band-pizza-velvet-underground">Macaulay Culkin</a>, <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0790057/reference">Alia Shawkat</a>, <a href="http://www.complex.com/covers/zoe-kravitz-interview-2015-cover-story/">Zoe Kravitz</a>, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/devendra-banhart">Devendra Banhart </a>and the Moldy Peaches’ guitarist Jack Dishel who plays a hilarious double role. Along with them are many more actors and musicians romping through a cartoon come to life – which is exactly what Green had in mind.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/macaulay-culkmacaulay-culkin-aladdin-arabian-nights-adam-green">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Terence Davies on avoiding Hollywood A-listers: 'I don't cast big names'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/terence-davies-british-film-director-sunset-song-agyness-deyn</link>
      <description><p>At a New York retrospective of his work, the storied British director spoke of his love of the American Songbook and how good he is at ‘death and misery’</p><p>With the aid of a cane the 70-year-old British film director Terence Davies bounded up to the podium at New York’s Museum of the Moving Image to warm the crowd with a little praise. “You have a lot to be proud of. My great debt is to American musicals. <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2015/01/the-great-american-songbook-isnt-dead/384764/">The American Songbook</a> is the greatest gift to the world.” The multiple award-winner, whose early works are music-drenched kaleidoscopic reflections of post-war Liverpool, exuded buoyant Americanophilia stating “the only good musicals are American,” before taking a snipe at Britain’s “Andrew Rice Pudding”.</p><p>Davies is on these shores just as Sunset Song, his adaptation of Lewis Grassic Gibbons’ novel that the Guardian’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/dec/03/sunset-song-review-agyness-deyn-roams-a-stunning-landscape">Peter Bradshaw calls</a> “sad, sombre and deeply satisfying”, makes its American debut. The Museum of the Moving Image is running a retrospective through this month, and Sunday’s triple-feature was a thorough soak in Davies’ inimitable blend of stylized, melancholy memory.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/terence-davies-british-film-director-sunset-song-agyness-deyn">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Juliet Stevenson: why I bought a double decker bus on eBay</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/juliet-stevenson-interview-departure-alan-rickman</link>
      <description><p>The actor talks about helping refugee children, losing her ‘big brother’ Alan Rickman – and why she turned down Steven Spielberg<br></p><p>First excursions on to eBay often tend toward the modest. A pair of shoes, a coffee table. A bicycle, at a push. Not so for Juliet Stevenson. “It’s surprisingly easy to buy a double-decker bus, you know, once you start looking,” says the 59-year-old actor, picking over a chicken salad in a London restaurant. “I immediately discovered that a red one costs twice as much. And older ones are better, if they’re working well, because the parts aren’t as complicated. There’s less to go wrong.” All this is said in a helpful manner, as though she has heard I might be in the market for a bus myself and is determined I make an informed purchase.<br></p><p>Celebrities are permitted their indulgences. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/interactive/2012/jun/22/larry-ellison-private-island-rich">Johnny Depp has an island</a>. <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2010/jun/19/rupert-grint-interview">Rupert Grint</a> owns an ice-cream van. Juliet Stevenson’s bus, however, cannot be written off as an eccentricity. After visiting the Calais refugee camp in February, she asked one of the volunteers what was needed. The surprising answer was that a double-decker would go down a treat. “There are hundreds of kids in the camp,” she explains. “You can take the seats out of the upper deck, turn it into a dormitory, and it can also be a day centre. It’s warm, dry, safe. No one can knock it down and, if necessary, it can be driven away.” Within a few weeks of returning, she and a friend had snapped up a blue bus for £5,500 and driven it to the camp.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/juliet-stevenson-interview-departure-alan-rickman">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Simon Helberg: from Big Bang nerd to Meryl Streep’s cartoonish pianist</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/05/simom-helberg-big-bang-theory-cartoonish-pianist-florence-foster-jenkins</link>
      <description><p>The Big Bang Theory star is like a walking exclamation mark as the accompanist to the awful soprano Florence Foster Jenkins. Will the role help to make him the Jennifer Aniston of his megahit sitcom?</p><p>Last year, Stephen Frears had&nbsp;a man round for tea. His name was <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0374865/" title="">Simon Helberg</a>, and Frears had just cast him as an accompanist in his new film, about a howlingly awful operatic soprano in 1940s New York who somehow still managed to sell out Carniege Hall faster than Frank Sinatra. Frears needed someone who could play&nbsp;piano as well as act – his composer, <a href="http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0006035/" title="">Alexandre Desplat</a>, tipped him off about Helberg. A happy meeting with the film’s star, Meryl Streep (“I just think he fell from heaven,” she explains), cemented the deal.</p><p>Anyway, after tea, Frears took his young protege for a stroll round Notting Hill. “People came out of their houses just to stare at him,” the director remembers. “They were <em>wide-eyed</em>. They couldn’t <em>believe</em> he was here. It was then I thought: ‘That show really <em>is</em>&nbsp;popular …’”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/05/simom-helberg-big-bang-theory-cartoonish-pianist-florence-foster-jenkins">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Naomie Harris: ‘I portray strong women because that’s what I know’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/01/naomie-harris-interview-our-kind-of-traitor-bond-moneypenny</link>
      <description><p>The modern Eve Moneypenny and star of forthcoming Le Carré adaptation Our Kind of Traitor on female directors, posh actors and why theatre’s not for her</p><p>“Oh gosh, someone’s had an accident there,” says actor Naomie Harris, sounding concerned. She’s in a car en route to the Dior show at Paris fashion week; such invitations have tumbled in since she played Winnie Mandela in 2013’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/jan/02/mandela-long-walk-freedom-review" title=""><em>Mandela: Long Walk to Freedom</em></a> and updated Eve Moneypenny in the Bond films <em>Skyfall</em> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/oct/21/spectre-review-james-bond-is-back-stylish-camp-and-sexily-pro-snowden" title=""><em>Spectre</em></a>. Harris, 39, began acting professionally aged nine, and after university (Cambridge) and drama school (Bristol Old Vic) she was cast by Danny Boyle in the dystopian <em>28 Days Later</em>. Her new movie is <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N5k4FBGtbMs" title=""><em>Our Kind of Traitor</em></a><em>,</em> an adaptation of the John le Carré novel, in which she and Ewan McGregor are an ordinary couple caught up with the Russian mafia while on holiday in Marrakech.</p><p><strong>Is going to fashion shows fun or professional obligation?</strong><br>I love fashion and I have a great stylist who introduced me to it, because I didn’t know anything about fashion before. Now we go every year to these shows and it’s just a fun thing to do. But it’s just for the red carpet, not everyday&nbsp;life.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/01/naomie-harris-interview-our-kind-of-traitor-bond-moneypenny">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Richard Linklater: ‘Someone’s living back there, and he’s murdered somebody’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/30/richard-linklater-film-director-murderer-lodger-simon-hattenstone</link>
      <description><p>As his lodger, a convicted murderer, is sent back to prison, the director talks about the Texan justice system, the art of storytelling – and why he’ll always be a slacker at heart</p><p>At the start of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/richard-linklater">Richard Linklater</a>’s 1992 breakthrough movie <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/1992/dec/03/1">Slacker</a>, a passenger in a cab monologues away about life and hope and the randomness of it all. The young man, played by Linklater himself, tells the driver about his weird dreams: having lunch with Tolstoy, being Frank Zappa’s roadie. He proceeds to create an alternate reality in which he stays at the bus station, rather than gets the cab, meets a cute girl, plays pinball with her, falls in love. Three minutes later, he gets out, saying: “Man! Shit. I should have stayed at the bus station.” It’s beautifully constructed, and in a way it became the template for all the films that followed.</p><p>Linklater doesn’t do drama. There is often no plot. His characters wander about, talk (how they talk!), fall in and out of love, get stoned and drunk and disappointed, make good and bad decisions. His films amble along gloriously, eavesdropping on life.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/30/richard-linklater-film-director-murderer-lodger-simon-hattenstone">Continue reading...</a></description>
