    <item>
      <title>Nick Broomfield: ‘I’ve always been fascinated by buildings and history’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/01/nick-broomfield-fascinated-buildings-history-liverpool-cardiff</link>
      <description>The documentary-maker on how his love of architecture has inspired two new films about Liverpool and Cardiff<p>In a pair of new TV documentaries, <em>Going Going Gone</em>, the film-maker Nick Broomfield visits two rotting and boarded-up relics of Britain’s 19th-century industrial wealth. One is the baroque-style <a href="http://coalexchange.co.uk/" title="">Coal Exchange in Cardif</a>f, the other the neoclassical <a href="http://www.heritageworks.co.uk/wellington.htm" title="">Wellington Rooms in Liverpool</a>. Both were created for moneyed classes – in the decades of Cardiff’s coal boom, traders in the exchange set the world’s price for the commodity; in the Wellington Rooms people made rich by slavery and shipping danced and partied. But both later became popular venues for the less privileged and ethnically mixed communities in which they stood. The Wellington Rooms were an Irish Centre until the late 1990s; the Coal Exchange was a venue for weddings, parties and concerts until its closure in 2013.</p><p>The films are shot in Broomfield’s distinctive style, in which he himself is a conspicuous presence, sometimes wielding a sound boom, sometimes pleading with unhelpful security staff as the rain falls on his clear plastic&nbsp;mac.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/01/nick-broomfield-fascinated-buildings-history-liverpool-cardiff">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Adam Green's Aladdin: ‘We did everything we could to make it not feel like work’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/adam-green-aladdin-the-moldy-peaches-macaulay-culkin</link>
      <description><p>Once half of indie oddballs the Moldy Peaches, Green has made the year’s craziest film, a lysergic take on the folk tale starring Macaulay Culkin. We cadge a few film-making pointers from a DIY auteur<br></p><p>The former <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/jun/07/features16.theguide5">Moldy Peaches</a> man Adam Green is best known as a charmingly scuzzy singer-songwriter with a curiously large following in Germany. But his latest labour of love is a warped, feature-length version of Aladdin, made on the cheap in a Brooklyn warehouse, and starring Macaulay Culkin and Arrested Development’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2013/may/20/arrested-development-season-four-netflix-sitcom">Alia Shawkat</a>. It’s a follow-up of sorts to a baffling film he made in 2011, <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Wrong_Ferarri">The Wrong Ferrari</a>, which was shot on iPhone and written on ketamine. Suffice to say that Green has his own hallucinogenic take on the Aladdin fable in which the princess is a reality TV star, the Sultan is a pot-bellied pervert and the lamp is a 3D printer that upsets the karmic balance of the universe by printing out an analogue version of the internet. How does a film as whacked-out as this get from drug-addled fever dream to the arthouse cinema screen? Let the man himself explain.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/adam-green-aladdin-the-moldy-peaches-macaulay-culkin">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jeremy Renner: ‘Acting gave me the freedom to feel rage or sadness in a safe way’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/jeremy-renner-acting-gave-me-the-freedom-to-feel-rage-or-sadness-in-a-safe-way</link>
      <description><p>The Avengers and Mission: Impossible star is famous not only for blockbusters but also as a great character actor. And then there’s the interior design</p><p>Jeremy Renner strides into the hotel room, shakes my hand (“Hey buddy”) and winces. It’s the air conditioning. Too cold. He goes over to the window and opens it. The curtains billow. Too breezy. While the publicist fixes the temperature, Renner sits down opposite me, crossing his arms and legs to keep himself warm. A good room, he says, is one where you would feel happy strolling around naked. A place in which to literally hang out. “That’s the idea. You’ve got to feel at ease.” Does this room fit the bill? He gazes around. “It might be a little big for my taste. I like a boutiquey feel. I go with emotion and instinct. How do we give each room its own beautiful energy? You might like a dual-colour couch and bright curtains. That’s fine. Me, I like these ones here. Something more muted.” He indicates the taupe curtains. It strikes me that I am being instructed in the principles of interior design by one of the Avengers.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/captain-america-civil-war-review-an-aspartame-rush">Captain America: Civil War review – an aspartame rush</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/jeremy-renner-acting-gave-me-the-freedom-to-feel-rage-or-sadness-in-a-safe-way">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Evolution director Lucile Hadžihalilović: ‘The starfish was the one worry’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/evolution-lucile-hadzihalilovic-starfish-worry-boys-mothers</link>
      <description>The enigmatic French film-maker is one of cinema’s few authentic visionaries. Her unsettling new film about maternity, boys and echinoderms makes it clear why hers has not been the easiest career to pursue<p>“I seem to have a bit of a problem with reality,” says Lucile Hadžihalilović. Or perhaps the French film-maker is just committed to&nbsp;a reality of her own. Her <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/sep/13/evolution-review-eerie-body-horror-toronto-film-festival" title="">new film, Evolution</a>, set on a mysterious island, is itself an enigmatic outcrop, far off cinema’s well-mapped charts. It depicts an uncanny world inhabited by young boys and their eerie mothers; curious medical procedures are carried out at the island’s hospital, placing the boys in&nbsp;uncomfortably close proximity with starfish. Part horror story, part visual poem, it shows why Hadžihalilović is one of the few authentic visionaries in cinema today. It also makes it clear why hers has not been the easiest career to pursue.</p><p>Evolution comes a full 12 years after her first film, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2005/sep/30/1" title="">Innocence</a> – itself a wistful nightmare, set in a girls’ school situated deep in a dark forest. Both films showcase an approach to sexuality and the corporeal that is, if not&nbsp;perverse, certainly nonconformist. They are films you would struggle to imagine on paper – which is why it took so long to get Evolution funded, she says. “People didn’t understand what the script was about. It’s a film about sensations, emotions – not storytelling – so people had to bring their imagination to the table. We really tried to explain it, but it’s the sort of film where, if you start, the whole thing collapses like a house of cards.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/evolution-lucile-hadzihalilovic-starfish-worry-boys-mothers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/27/sadie-frost-interview-set-the-thames-on-fire</link>
      <description><p>The designer and actor on her return to film in Set the Thames on Fire, floods, fashion and Mars bars</p><p><strong>Hi, Sadie. You’ve produced and star in a new film, <a href="http://www.setthethamesonfire.com/">Set the Thames on Fire</a>. What’s it all about?</strong></p><p>It’s set in a dystopian, futuristic London, where London has flooded and the dark, toxic, crazy dregs of society are left behind. I play a disgusting, foul-mouthed landlady who’s got an eye for young boys. It’s got a great cast, including <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/sally-phillips">Sally Phillips</a> and <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/video/2015/jun/15/noel-fielding-self-portrait-im-a-pointy-old-witch-video">Noel Fielding</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/27/sadie-frost-interview-set-the-thames-on-fire">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Director Yuri Bykov: 'Russian viewers get angry with me'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/26/yury-bykov-the-fool-interview</link>
      <description><p>The Russian film-maker discusses The Fool, his latest study of corruption, moral compromise and the behaviour of people in impossible situations</p><p>Yuri Bykov’s The Fool opens with a man beating up his wife and daughter, and gets progressively darker from there. Russian movies are not generally known for their frivolity, but Bykov’s output makes <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/nov/06/leviathan-director-andrei-zvyagintsev-russia-oscar-contender-film">Andrei Zvyagintsev’s Leviathan</a>, notable for its soul-crushing gloominess, look like an upbeat romcom by comparison.<br></p><p>The Fool is set in an unnamed provincial Russian town where the local elite cream cash off the budget while the majority of the population live in abject poverty. The eponymous fool is Dima Nikitin, a municipal plumber who realises that a huge apartment block is in such a sorry state it could collapse at any moment. Much to the horror of his parents, his wife, his superiors and the town’s administration, he embarks on a quest to have the building evacuated before disaster strikes. It does not go well, to put it mildly.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/26/yury-bykov-the-fool-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Selling Serco: documentary-maker Molly Dineen on why she shot a corporate promo</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/molly-dineen-serco-corporate-documentary-interview-rupert-soames</link>
      <description><p>Molly Dineen has made an inhouse film for crisis-hit firm Serco full of happy prisoners and grateful asylum-seekers. Why?<br></p><p>‘How do we make our people feel less like shit?” This was one of the most pressing questions for Rupert Soames when he took control of the crisis-ridden outsourcing firm Serco.</p><p><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/business/2015/jul/02/serco-rupert-soames-outsourcing-privatisation">The £1.05bn organisation</a> – which runs prisons, air-traffic control hubs, train lines and government defence contracts globally – was in the midst of a “full-blown corporate crisis, and as a company it was widely reviled”, says Soames, who became chief executive in May 2014. Staff morale was extremely low. “We seek to make the world a better place, and then we see all of these headlines: ‘evil’, ‘grasping’, ‘ripping off the taxpayer’,” he adds, suggesting that it was “a bit like if you were a member of a congregation and discovered that your priest had been doing crack cocaine”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/molly-dineen-serco-corporate-documentary-interview-rupert-soames">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Jake Gyllenhaal: ‘Pushing myself is part of my life’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/jake-gyllenhaal-interview-pushing-myself-is-part-of-my-life-film-demolition</link>
      <description><p>Jake Gyllenhaal has driven his body to the limit for his acting roles. Now it’s his mind that’s taking a hammering. He talks to Tim Adams</p><p>I meet Jake Gyllenhaal in a makeshift production office in an industrial estate outside Boston, Massachusetts. He is bright-eyed and sitting in a bare corner room. He closes the door on his dog, a big Alsatian, which roams outside among a team of assistants staring at screens and eating lunch. He has been here for six months making <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/30/jake-gyllenhaal-stronger-jeff-bauman-boston-marathon-bombing"><em>Stronger</em></a>, a film based on the life of <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/apr/14/boston-bombing-wheelchair-photo-one-year-later">Jeff Bauman</a>, who lost his legs in the <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/boston-marathon-bombing">Boston Marathon bombing</a> and then identified one of the killers, who he had stood next to in the crowd. Gyllenhaal, who has a legendary work ethic, is both starring in and producing the film. He’s got to know Bauman well. “The irony is that, however terrible the situation was, it gave him a real meaning and purpose,” he says. “Jeff is quite a character. A hilarious person. The movie is very funny. It is a story of someone who had to learn how to become a father and an adult through an unbelievably difficult and horrific situation. It is a story of how to grow up.”</p><p>Gyllenhaal spent five months working in the LAPD, and witnessed a murder during a drugs bust</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/jake-gyllenhaal-interview-pushing-myself-is-part-of-my-life-film-demolition">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Cillian Murphy: ‘Is this it, for the rest of my days?’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/23/cillian-murphy-peaky-blinders-batman-scarecrow-tom-lamont</link>
      <description><p>He’s found a new audience as the violent lead in Peaky Blinders. But as he turns 40, the actor contemplates what comes next</p><p>Soon it will be <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/cillian-murphy">Cillian Murphy</a>’s birthday. “I’ll be turning 40,” the Irish actor says. “Just a couple of months.” A placid and even-spoken man, Cork-born and with an iron Corkonian modesty at the core of him, Murphy does not sound overjoyed about his approaching milestone. But neither does he sound histrionic or weepy. Last night, he says, he was in bed by 10, falling asleep to the comforting murmur of <a href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006qtl3">The World Tonight</a> on Radio 4. These days, this is not even an uncommon scenario. “I feel like I’m entering a different phase of my life,” he says. “I don’t mind embracing it. I had a really good time in my 20s and 30s. Now I’m ready for a bit more… decorum, I guess? A bit more moderation? Still enjoying being a young man, but looking over the wall into the other side, you know?”</p><p>It’s funny to hear Murphy speak this way about getting on, especially because the 39-year-old could still be mistaken, at first glance, for a teenager. We meet in a London park on a bright and chilly spring day, and it strikes me that Murphy (slender, slouching, his cheeks reddened by cold and a long fringe swept boyishly to one side) would not look out of place with a muddy football under his arm. “It’s only an advantage as an actor,” he smiles when I point this out, “looking younger than you are. If you can maintain it.” </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/23/cillian-murphy-peaky-blinders-batman-scarecrow-tom-lamont">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Richard Madden: ‘I don’t want to get up at 4am for something I don’t care about’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/richard-madden-bastille-day-idris-elba-game-of-thrones</link>
      <description><p>First he was Robb Stark in Game Of Thrones, then Lady Chatterley’s hunky gamekeeper. Now he’s winding up Idris Elba in buddy action film Bastille Day. Meet an actor going places</p><p>Richard Madden can recall with clarity the moment he crossed the line with Idris Elba. The “odd couple”, as Madden describes himself and his Bastille Day co-star, were just days into the action film’s three-month shoot in Paris. The 29-year-old actor plays a pickpocket who becomes the unlikely partner-in-crime of a former CIA agent (enter Elba, giving the Bond audition of his life). They had been rehearsing for a car chase, and were preparing for the first take, when Madden decided to wind Elba up. “I turned to him and I said: ‘Are you going to do it like that on the take?’” Suddenly there was tension in the air. “I could see him thinking: ‘What the fuck’s this guy doing?’ It was great. At the end of the scene, he realised what I was doing and was like: ’You’re a fucker! You’re just trying to fuck me up!’” Madden laughs, then lets out a long breath. “He could have taken it the wrong way…”</p><p>The opening passage of Bastille Day, in which Elba’s agent chases Madden’s petty thief across Paris, sets a pace that doesn’t let up. But though the film serves up plenty of moments for Elba to showcase his action-man talents, it’s also an effective two-hander. The dynamic between the duo develops into something reminiscent of the odd action couples of old (in Lethal Weapon or 48 Hrs). When, on the verge of big shootout, Madden’s character asks Elba: “Can I have a gun?”, and gets a withering glower in return, it feels like Joe Pesci pestering Mel Gibson. Madden says that he improvised the line, and you can tell he’s proud it made the final cut.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/22/richard-madden-bastille-day-idris-elba-game-of-thrones">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Isabelle Huppert: ‘When I act, I don't think about anything’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/isabelle-huppert-when-i-act-i-dont-think-about-anything</link>
      <description><p>Famous for immersing herself in challenging roles, the French actor plays a war photographer in her latest film Louder Than Bombs. She talks about her commitment to directors, acting with Gerard Depardieu and playing a woman who stalks her rapist</p><p>Isabelle Huppert strides into the salon, full of pep and vinegar, as you would expect. “Right now, I am completely immersed in theatre,” she says, not especially apologetically. “That’s why I might sound a little asleep at times.” It’s true: she is midway through a two-month Paris run of <a href="http://www.theatre-odeon.eu/en/2015-2016/spectacles/phedres">Phaedra(s)</a>, the classical Greek tragedy as reinterpreted by Sarah “Blasted” Kane, Wajdi Mouawad and JM Coetzee. “It is a very demanding production,” she says, and you wouldn’t want to doubt her.</p><p>But she doesn’t sound in the remotest bit asleep. One of Huppert’s principal attributes, and one that has served her brilliantly as an actor over the decades, is her wide-awake steeliness and resolution beneath the unassuming exterior, the toughness and wariness of someone who is not going to be messed with. Now 63, she has been making films for more than 40 years, ever since bagging a small role in the 1972 teen comedy Faustine et le Bel Été. (She didn’t play Faustine, but the cast also included future heavy-hitters Isabelle Adjani and Nathalie Baye.) She’s now completed more than 100 films, a decent percentage of which are masterpieces. What’s her secret and why does she keep going? Has she ever thought of packing it in?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/isabelle-huppert-when-i-act-i-dont-think-about-anything">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Anthony LaPaglia on American politics and ageism in Hollywood</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/anthony-lapaglia-on-why-so-many-hollywood-stars-are-making-big-flops</link>
      <description><p>LA-based Australian actor says Hollywood decision makers are mostly business graduates that ‘crunch numbers’ rather than make sound artistic choices</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/guardian-film-club-gala-screening-a-month-of-sundays">Book now for Guardian Australia’s screening of A Month of Sundays, on 27 April</a></li></ul><p>In Anthony LaPaglia’s new film A Month of Sundays, the latest work from <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/australia-culture-blog/2014/oct/31/noise-rewatched-australian-police-drama-at-its-sophisticated-best">Noise</a> and Felony director Matthew Saville, the 57-year-old actor plays a grumpy Eeyore-like housing broker who walks around in a permanent funk. His character, Frank Mollard, is dour and reserved; a man of few words.</p><p>This is in stark contrast to the person who plays him; when we speak, he is at a Bondi hotel having landed just a few hours ago on a flight from LA. LaPaglia is loquacious and engaging, rattling through topics with the kind of straight-shooting, borderline brazen sincerity often associated with beer-infused pub banter (it’s mid-afternoon and we’re drinking coffee).<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/anthony-lapaglia-on-why-so-many-hollywood-stars-are-making-big-flops">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Gurinder Chadha on Viceroy’s House: why I had to make a film about partition</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/16/gurinder-chadha-on-viceroys-house-why-i-had-to-make-a-film-about-partition</link>
      <description><p>I burst into tears when I found the house my grandfather was forced to abandon in Pakistan in 1947, and I knew then I finally had to tell our family’s story</p><p>It was rumoured in Agra that, during the 1971 war between India and Pakistan, Pakistani bombers would be guided to their target by the gleaming marble of the Taj Mahal. Yet it stands as a towering example of how Islamic culture is so organically part of India’s heritage, despite the sometimes uneasy relationship between the two countries.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/gallery/2016/apr/11/prince-william-and-kate-visit-india-in-pictures">Prince William and Kate visit India – in pictures</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/apr/16/gurinder-chadha-on-viceroys-house-why-i-had-to-make-a-film-about-partition">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Who ya gonna call? Why Ghostbusters is leading the charge for female buddy movies</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/01/who-ya-gonna-call-why-ghostbusters-is-leading-the-charge-for-female-buddy-movies</link>
      <description><p>The eagerly awaited reboot replaces the four male characters of the original with women. Could it be a game changer for Hollywood? ‘Everyone needs to step up,’ says its director, Paul Feig</p><p>Wednesday 27 April was <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Administrative_Professionals%27_Day">Administrative Professionals’ Day</a>, formerly National Secretaries Day – an annual celebration begun in the US in 1952. A <a href="http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/recycled/2010/04/keep_your_roses.html">heavily gendered</a> date, it is traditionally an opportunity for <a href="http://theproducenews.com/more-floral-articles/floral/12438-administrative-professionals-day-stealth-holiday-for-floral-trade">florists</a> and chocolatiers. But this year, a movie grabbed a slice of the pie. That movie was <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/ghostbusters-first-trailer-all-female-reboot-kristen-wiig-melissa-mccarthy">Ghostbusters</a>, the forthcoming reboot of the beloved supernatural comedy that sees Melissa McCarthy, Kristen Wiig, Leslie Jones and Kate McKinnon don the jumpsuits once worn by Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis and Ernie Hudson.</p><p>In Ivan Reitman’s <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2011/oct/27/my-favourite-film-ghostbusters">1984 original</a>, the secretary was Janine: goggle glasses, pixie cut, questionable telephone manner (“Waddya want?”). In Paul Feig’s version, it’s Kevin: a ditzy blond hired for his hunkiness not his shorthand. The clips <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4cCqOZDu2-w">released to coincide with Administrative Professionals’ Day </a>– Kevin baffled by the phone, botching the tea run, eagerly drafting inappropriate logos (think busty ghosts) – brilliantly showcase the gender flip that is one of the movie’s key USPs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/may/01/who-ya-gonna-call-why-ghostbusters-is-leading-the-charge-for-female-buddy-movies">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>The actor appears in this week’s Knight of Cups, Terrence Malick’s ponderous look at LA’s rich and famous, but what have his finest career choices been?</p><p>The past 12 months have seen Antonio Banderas star as both a food-obsessed pirate called Burger-Beard in The Spongebob Movie: Sponge Out of Water and a party-lounging playboy in Terrence Malick’s latest, Knight of Cups.     <item>
      <title>I Am Wrath: John Travolta gives in to the geri-action genre</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/07/i-am-wrath-john-travolta</link>
      <description><p>A veteran actor takes justice into his own hands to avenge a brutal murder. Sound familiar?</p><p>Crime is down,” proclaims the liberal governor of Ohio in the opening scenes of the new action thriller I Am Wrath (available to stream from Monday). His assertion may be in line with statistical reality – the US crime rate has indeed fallen consistently since the mid 1990s – but as any red-blooded American can tell you, statistics can be used to prove damn near anything.</p><p>The real story is to be found on the streets, or – in the case of John Travolta’s unemployed family man Stanley Hill – in the multistorey car park where his wife is brutally murdered for loose change by a gang of strung-out hoodlums. After identifying the ringleader in a police lineup, Hill is confident that justice will be served, but the feeble cops would rather give the killer a lollipop for good behaviour than put him behind bars where he belongs. Again, a statistician might point out that the US is actually far from squeamish when it comes to mass incarceration, but consider this: maybe the US’s prison population is not in fact the largest in the world, but the least unlargest.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/07/i-am-wrath-john-travolta">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mary Pickford: America's first screen megastar</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/mary-pickford-silent-film-megastar-gladys-smith-actor-producer-mogul</link>
      <description><p>Her natural acting style made her the world’s pre-eminent silent cinema actor, but Pickford, born Gladys Smith, also became a producer and an early film mogul</p><p>The first thing to know about America’s sweetheart is that she was Canadian. It’s not so remarkable for a young actor to move to the States to seek work on Broadway, and eventually an undreamt-of place called Hollywood, nor for that person to change their name as soon as they find success. But the career of Mary Pickford, born Gladys Smith in Toronto in 1892, has been so often misrepresented that it is best to begin with the facts of the case, and not secondhand impressions.</p><p>Mary Pickford was an actor of great, unrivalled skill, a producer and a businesswoman. She emerged from poverty and a broken family to become a star who was loved by millions but also powerful behind the scenes. And contrary to many misapprehensions, she was capable of playing a wide range of roles, not just the little-girl parts she is most often associated with.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/mary-pickford-silent-film-megastar-gladys-smith-actor-producer-mogul">Continue reading...</a></description>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/celebrity">Celebrity</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/silent-film">Silent film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film">Film</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/culture">Culture</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lifeandstyle">Life and style</category>
      <category domain="https://www.theguardian.com/film/film-industry">Film industry</category>
      <pubDate>Mon, 25 Apr 2016 07:53:45 GMT</pubDate>
      <guid>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/mary-pickford-silent-film-megastar-gladys-smith-actor-producer-mogul</guid>
      <media:content width="140" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a27be23974294d388b760c4f01147bc2d01849e9/0_463_1900_1139/1900.jpg?w=140&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=0047d50cea522307cbf1abb675989f4d">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Popperfoto/Getty Images</media:credit>
      </media:content>
      <media:content width="460" url="https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a27be23974294d388b760c4f01147bc2d01849e9/0_463_1900_1139/1900.jpg?w=460&q=55&auto=format&usm=12&fit=max&s=1ed237eb9830f421675bf64c501fdd00">
        <media:credit scheme="urn:ebu">Photograph: Popperfoto/Getty Images</media:credit>

    <item>
      <title>The Hateful Eight; Room; A War; Welcome to Me; Janis: Little Girl Blue; Welcome to Leith – review</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/08/hateful-eight-room-janis-little-girl-blue-welcome-to-leith-dvd-reviews</link>
      <description>Quentin Tarantino’s western locks eight of the usual suspects in a cabin together, but none can match Brie Larson for captivating viewing<p>Winter may finally have thawed, sending us warily out into the scattered sunlight, but this week’s DVD slate is an unseasonably interior affair – led by a pair of literal chamber pieces. In <strong>The Hateful Eight</strong> (EIV, 18), Agatha Christie proves an unexpected addition to Quentin Tarantino’s long list of pop-thriller influences. Cramming its crusty ensemble of rogues in a snowbound Wyoming log cabin for the better part of three long hours, this bounty-hunter face-off amounts to a pressure cooker of post-civil war tension and resentment.</p><p>As tangled backstories of vengeance and violation emerge between the eponymous octet of gunslingers, it’s obvious that few will survive this cosy deathtrap. The game is in what order and formation they’ll fall. Tarantino, for his part, doesn’t seem that invested in the outcome: this ugly cat’s cradle of murderous agendas serves as a mere hanging structure for his trademark bursts of extreme violence and extravagant verbiage. Tarantino cannot under-deliver in those departments, but this nonetheless feels stiff and passionless by his standards. Shot in gleaming 70mm Panavision and scored to shivering, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8977YNfJdBU">Oscar-winning effect by Ennio Morricone</a>, the film elegantly exposes bloody reserves of American social and racial prejudice, and is too enamoured of its own lustrous cinematic surface to probe them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/08/hateful-eight-room-janis-little-girl-blue-welcome-to-leith-dvd-reviews">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Secret Actress on sex scenes: my co-star warned ‘forgive me if I harden'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/secret-actress-sex-scenes-forgive-me-if-i-harden</link>
      <description><p>In her column lifting the lid on the film and TV industry, an Oscar and Golden Globe-nominated actor explains why nothing’s creepier than simulating sex </p><p>Having sex is fun. Having sex in front of your co-workers, with a co-worker, is the stuff of anxiety dreams to the power of 10. I once had an anxiety dream about having to do a sex scene the night before I had to do a sex scene. It was the most bizarre experience to wake up in horror, then to feel the massive wash of relief that it was just a dream only to be hit with the realization that it was about to be real. That’s some meta shit right there. </p><p>Whatever adulation/irritation you might have with certain actors/actresses, know that doing sex scenes is them having to pay the piper in full, with interest. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/19/secret-actress-sex-scenes-forgive-me-if-i-harden">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Our Kind Of Traitor: is the Brit spy movie creating its own cinematic universe?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/le-carre-british-spy-movie-our-kind-of-traitor</link>
      <description><p>As the latest John Le Carré film shows, the worlds of George Smiley, James Bond and Harry Palmer have never been closer<br></p><p>Is it just me or are the John le Carré and James Bond movie franchises slowly converging? At the very least, these two still-distinct, venerable, 1960s-era espionage universes are talking to each other, if only in a wink-wink fashion. In the Craig years, the 007 franchise has arguably acquired a soupçon – no more than that – of the emotional urgency and squalid moral compromise that animates Le Carré’s spooks. </p><p>Meanwhile, what are we to make of the fact that in the latest Le Carré adaptation, <strong>Our Kind Of Traitor</strong>, one of the leads is played by Miss Moneypenny herself, Naomie Harris? Or of that phone number handed to Jonathan Pine in The Night Manager: 44 7007 707070? Or that Zermatt, the Swiss town in that series, is shot so as to evoke On Her Majesty’s Secret Service? And are not The Night Manager’s opening credits – all martini glasses morphing into mushroom clouds, etc – as Bond-ian, or as Maurice Binder-ish, as Skyfall’s?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/09/le-carre-british-spy-movie-our-kind-of-traitor">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Beyond Twilight: on the set of Personal Shopper with Kristen Stewart</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/beyond-twilight-on-the-set-of-personal-shopper-with-kristen-stewart</link>
      <description><p>One of the most hotly anticipated films at Cannes sees Kristen Stewart playing a clairvoyant shopper to the stars. We join the intense, elusive actor on set in Prague</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2016/apr/14/cannes-2016-lineup-peter-bradshaw-verdict">Cannes 2016: big names and some great Brits swell an exciting lineup | Peter Bradshaw</a> </p><p>On a bracingly cold December morning, a cottage complete with miniature lawn and garden trellis stands inside a studio on the outskirts of Prague. Inside, Kristen Stewart is running through a scene from the supernatural thriller Personal Shopper. Overseeing it is <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/olivier-assayas">Olivier Assayas</a>, the writer-director responsible for coaxing from the 26-year-old a revelatory performance in <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/14/clouds-of-sils-maria-review-juliette-binoche-kristen-stewart">Clouds of Sils Maria</a>. In that film, she was Val, the straight-shooting, unsentimental assistant to an insecure star played by Juliette Binoche. Stewart’s work for Assayas made her the first American woman to win a <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jan/27/cesar-film-award-nominations-announced">César award, France’s equivalent of an Oscar</a>. And word has just reached Prague that the New York Film Critics Circle have <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/jan/05/new-york-film-critics-circle-awards-carol-michael-keaton-saoirse-ronan">also awarded Stewart a prize</a>. “It’s a real possibility now that she could get an Oscar nomination,” says Charles Gillibert, the producer of both Clouds and Personal Shopper, as we mill around on set. (She didn’t.)</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/beyond-twilight-on-the-set-of-personal-shopper-with-kristen-stewart">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>It’s clunky in places and has some very suspect accents, but the new biopic is far from the only own goal in the Brazilian legend’s on-screen back catalogue </p><p>Originally scheduled to appear in time for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil, the long-delayed Pelé: Birth of a Legend – the first ever biopic of the soccer legend – is finally being released.       <title>Green Room: inside the punk Patrick Stewart thriller that's making people sick</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/patrick-stewart-jeremy-saulnier-green-room-thriller-punks-v-fascists</link>
      <description><p>Jeremy Saulnier’s horror-thriller pits a punk band against neo-Nazis in a bloody battle of survival. The director explains why he wants you to squirm</p><p>Green Room has been making people sick. People have said they’ve stopped breathing during the film; that watching it made them feel unsafe. When he read the script for the first time, Patrick Stewart was so unsettled he stopped after 30 pages to ensure all his windows and doors were locked, then poured himself a scotch (once he’d read the rest, he signed up immediately to play the film’s merciless neo-Nazi Darcy). Jeremy Saulnier loves all of this. He likes upsetting people.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/17/green-room-review-horror-cannes-film-festival-2015-patrick-stewart">Green Room review - gruesomely effective neo-Nazis vs rockers horror</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/10/patrick-stewart-jeremy-saulnier-green-room-thriller-punks-v-fascists">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Lonely rangers: the dark side of westerns</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/dark-side-westerns-film-bfi-season-ride-lonesome</link>
      <description><p>The early cowboy movies were built on a simple moral struggle between goodies and baddies. So why did they so quickly evolve into psychologically bleak depictions of damaged souls?</p><p>Among the rocks and dust of an Arizona canyon, a man and a woman want to kill each other. Each draws closer, gun in hand, and they take turns to fire, inflicting wounds. Yet between each shot, the desire they feel for one another overwhelms them. Here, love reveals itself as murderous, and murder proves loving. Mortally wounded, the woman crawls through the dust so they may die, stilled at last, in each other’s arms. The scene is over-the-top, it is preposterous, and yet in being so it is also exceedingly magnificent. From <a href="http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0038499/"><em>Duel in the Sun</em></a> (1946), David O Selznick and King Vidor’s delirium-dream of a movie, this moment encapsulates the operatic astonishment of the postwar Hollywood western, with a shootout that sets the tone for the genre’s descent into hallucinatory strangeness. From then on, the vast distances of the American landscape would be matched by the depth of fall into the human psyche.</p><p>Until then the western had stood as a realm of almost heraldic simplicities, a moral landscape in which the good and the bad square up; black hats versus white hats, and all stays firmly in its place, especially the foundational dominion that is America itself. Within a pristine wilderness, new, disconcerting complexities became manifest. Neurosis and social disorder itself could ascend to the status of legend, the petty problems of the individual soul raised up into something archetypal.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/06/dark-side-westerns-film-bfi-season-ride-lonesome">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'May the Fourth' be with you: a look at Rian Johnson's Star Wars: Episode VIII</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/04/rian-johnson-star-wars-episode-viii-everything-we-know</link>
      <description><p>Rey’s true parentage, Maz Kanata’s connection to the Force and Phasma’s trash compactor survival skills are among the puzzles waiting to be solved </p><p>Great solar storms of uncertainty swirl around Star Wars: Episode VIII, written and directed by Rian Johnson. Will the upcoming sequel to JJ Abrams’ The Force Awakens continue to plough the hyper-nostalgic furrow that <a href="http://www.boxofficemojo.com/alltime/domestic.htm">helped make its predecessor the highest-grossing movie of all time at the domestic box office</a>, or risk shifting the space opera saga into uncharted territory? Will Johnson begin to unravel the mysteries surrounding key figures such as Daisy Ridley’s Rey, Lupita Nyong’o’s Maz Kanata and Mark Hamill’s Luke Skywalker? And what will happen to Chewbacca’s furry fuzzball hide now that Han Solo’s not around to help him out with a frequent trim? To answer all these questions, and in celebration of May the Fourth, here’s everything we’ve been able to glean so far about Star Wars: Episode VIII.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/21/rumoured-leaked-script-reveals-star-wars-episode-viii-plot-rey-force">Star Wars: Episode VIII 'leaked script' reveals rumoured plot twists</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/04/rian-johnson-star-wars-episode-viii-everything-we-know">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Welcome to the sausage party! Why we're about to see a new golden age of rude cartoons</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/why-were-heading-into-a-new-age-of-r-rated-animated-films-seth-rogen-sausage-party</link>
      <description><p>Deadpool’s enormous success bodes well for Seth Rogen’s R-rated SXSW hit – plus plenty more rude cartoons coming down the pipe</p><p>We’re not yet into summer, but already this year, the cinema-going public has made two things abundantly clear to Hollywood: it likes its comedy profane, and it prefers pixels to humans.</p><p>Deadpool, Ryan Reynolds’ foul-mouthed and wildly irreverent superhero flick, shocked the industry in February by scoring the highest opening of all time for an R-rated film. A month later it became <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/29/deadpool-becomes-highest-grossing-r-rated-film-of-all-time-ryan-reynolds">the biggest R-rated success of all time</a>. In the US, it’s so far amassed a staggering $361m (£246m), significantly more than the PG-13-rated comic book movie Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice, which boasts a larger budget and more recognisable characters. Worldwide, Deadpool has beaten Batman v Superman – but the former was banned in China, significantly impacting its overall revenue.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/29/why-were-heading-into-a-new-age-of-r-rated-animated-films-seth-rogen-sausage-party">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>From Toto to Beethoven, dogs get our tails wagging at the flicks. But how about if they’re no longer alive and licking? Zoe Williams watches Heart of a Dog, Laurie Anderson’s lament for Lolabelle</p><p>“For two years after her death,” run <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2016/apr/19/how-we-made-laurie-anderson-o-superman">Laurie Anderson</a>’s studiedly monotonous tones in <a href="http://www.heartofadogfilm.com/">Heart of a Dog</a>, “I continued to get Facebook notifications from Lolabelle – from a Facebook account I didn’t know she had.” She is talking about her rat terrier, who predeceased her, as dogs are wont. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/music/2016/mar/27/laurie-anderson-interview-q-and-a-heart-dog-lolabelle-terrier-brighton-festival-lou-reed-o-superman">Laurie Anderson: ‘My dog’s character was pure empathy.     <item>
      <title>Sherpa and beyond: ten of the best Australian documentaries</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/documentaries-have-told-australian-stories-since-celluloid-arrived-heres-10-of-the-best</link>
      <description><p>From ‘rats’ in politics to cane toads in Queensland via ice-bitten tragedies in Everest and Antarctica, we round up the best documentaries from Australia</p><p>Documentaries have been a part of Australian film history from the beginning. A whole 10 years before <a draggable="true" href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/06/the-story-of-the-kelly-gang-rewatched-the-worlds-first-feature-length-film">The Story of the Kelly Gang claimed the title as the world’s first feature-length movie</a>, Marius Sestier was making nonfiction short films that detailed the extravagance of the annual Melbourne Cup and the mundanity of passengers disembarking from a paddle steamer at Manly. Not too long later, photographer Frank Hurley was documenting his travels to Antarctica in South and Home of the Blizzard.</p><p>Sestier, an employee at the time of film pioneers the Lumière brothers in France, is just one of many documentarians whose importance to Australian cinema culture has long been ignored. It’s disappointing considering documentaries are frequently among the world-class cinema this country produces; even our first Academy award winner was a documentary: Ken G Hall’s 1942 newsreel Kokoda Front Line.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/28/documentaries-have-told-australian-stories-since-celluloid-arrived-heres-10-of-the-best">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/straight-to-the-pool-room-top-ten-films-about-the-australian-dream</link>
      <description><p>The housing market may not sound like the most stimulating territory for a story, but it has been the basis of some of Australia’s greatest films</p><ul><li><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/12/guardian-film-club-gala-screening-a-month-of-sundays">Book now for Guardian Australia’s screening of A Month of Sundays, on 27 April</a></li></ul><p>Upcoming Adelaide-shot drama A Month of Sundays revolves around the real estate industry, through the story of a shonky broker (Anthony LaPaglia) who is inspired to change his ways. Meanwhile a young married couple, desperate to crack the housing market, are blocked out by bigger spenders. </p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/20/anthony-lapaglia-on-why-so-many-hollywood-stars-are-making-big-flops">Anthony LaPaglia on American politics and ageism in Hollywood</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/25/straight-to-the-pool-room-top-ten-films-about-the-australian-dream">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Psycho thrillers: five movies that teach us how the mind works</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/psycho-thrillers-five-movies-how-mind-works-psychologists</link>
      <description><p>Power, violence, death and reality … the movies can teach us plenty about life’s big issues. From the Godfather to Groundhog Day, five psychologists pick the films that tell us what makes humans tick</p><p>Ten days ago in London, the Hungarian director László Nemes hosted a preview screening of his film, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/son-of-saul">Son of Saul</a>. He explained that if people didn’t want to stay for the Q&amp;A afterwards, that was fine; he wouldn’t take personal offence. The audience giggled politely. “That’s the last laugh you’ll have for a while,” he told them.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/psycho-thrillers-five-movies-how-mind-works-psychologists">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>At last, a film about the 80s that tells it like it was … without  leg-warmers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/1980s-films-nostalgia-history-richard-linklater-everybody-wants-some</link>
      <description>Richard Linklater’s Everybody Wants Some!! re-creates a 1980s adolescence that will seem alien to today’s teens<p>The ageing process may be gradual but the realisation that it is fully under way is like a large penny (or shilling, depending on your age) dropping with an unwelcome clang. One morning, there is simply a creased saddlebag staring back at you from the mirror where your vibrant youthful visage used to be.</p><p>A similar experience happens in the cinema when movies about events or eras that are still fresh in the mind begin to be packaged as history. To anyone in their 40s or 50s, seeing Richard Linklater’s new film <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/11/everybody-wants-some-review-richard-linklater" title=""><em>Everybody Wants Some!!</em></a>, set in Texas over three days in 1980, is likely to feel as though it was made yesterday. The film opens on a shot of an in-car tape deck; on the back seat there is a box of vinyl records. Behind the wheel is Jake (Blake Jenner), a wide-eyed college freshman. He and his team-mates wear too-short shorts and too-high knee-socks on the baseball field. They blow-dry their hair before hitting the disco in extravagantly patterned shirts that could induce a migraine at 40 paces.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/apr/24/1980s-films-nostalgia-history-richard-linklater-everybody-wants-some">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Woody Allen at Cannes: artistic competition 'against common sense'</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/woody-allen-cannes-film-festival-cafe-society-artistic-competition</link>
      <description><p>Director says perks of fame outweigh pitfalls as stars of new film Café Society critique ‘dog-eat-dog’ media and Allen’s estranged son publishes damning article </p><p>Woody Allen, whose new film opens this year’s Cannes film festival, has called the concept of artistic competition nonsensical. Speaking on the festival’s first day, Allen – whose 47th movie, Café Society, is not in contention for the Palme d’Or – said that although in sport pitting people against one another was “great”, in culture it was “against my common sense”. </p><p>“For any group to come together and judge the work of other people is something I would never do. To make a judgment that this is the best, with the implication that in some platonic way it is the objective ‘best’, is something I don’t believe in. So I don’t want to participate in it.”</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/woody-allen-cannes-film-festival-cafe-society-artistic-competition">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Café Society review – Woody Allen's amiable, if insubstantial, tribute to golden-age Hollywood</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/cafe-society-review-woody-allen-kristen-stewart-jesse-eisenberg</link>
      <description><p>Jesse Eisenberg and Kristen Stewart give excellent performances as an on-the-make New Yorker and the woman he falls in love with in Allen’s likable romance</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/woody-allen-cannes-film-festival-cafe-society-artistic-competition">Woody Allen at Cannes: artistic competition 'against common sense'</a> </p><p>Woody Allen’s Café Society is a sweet, sad, insubstantial jeu d’ésprit, watchable, charming and beautifully shot by Vittorio Storaro – yet always freighted with a pedantic nostalgia for the 1930s golden age in both Hollywood and New York, nostalgia which the title itself rather coercively announces. The movie boasts charming and intelligent lead performances from Kristen Stewart and Jesse Eisenberg – a career-highlight for Eisenberg, actually, who plays a white tuxedo-ed Manhattan nightclub manager whose broken heart has caused him to undergo a Bogartian growing up: from a gauche boy to a mature, disillusioned man, trapped in the wrong marriage.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/11/cafe-society-review-woody-allen-kristen-stewart-jesse-eisenberg">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Clooney interview: ‘Donald Trump is a xenophobic fascist’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist</link>
      <description><p>The superstar is playing a ‘numbskull’ for the Coens again in Hollywood satire Hail, Caesar! In an exclusive interview he talks about why he should have cast more black actors, the stranger-than-fiction presidential campaign and his faith in fellow Americans to ‘do the right thing’</p><p>George Clooney opens the door of the Berlin hotel lounge and shakes hands like an ambassador. “Come on in,” says this paragon of modern Hollywood: a proper, old-fashioned movie star; a producer and occasionally director of interesting, intelligent films; and a furrowed-brow liberal political activist of not inconsiderable achievement. Who else would spend the morning after the premiere of his new film, the Coen brothers’ Hail, Caesar!, <a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/feb/12/george-clooney-meets-angela-merkel-germany-support-refugees">confabbing with Angela Merkel</a> about the international refugee crisis? He should be running for president, surely?</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="http://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/hail-caesar-review-george-clooney-bigger-broader-zanier-in-classic-coen-caper">Hail, Caesar! review – George Clooney bigger, broader, zanier in classic Coen caper</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/mar/03/george-clooney-donald-trump-is-a-xenophobic-fascist">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Seventh Fire review – bleak, poetic look at two men on the edge</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/the-seventh-fire-review-documentary-terrence-malick-native-americans</link>
      <description><p>Two troubled Native American men take stock of their mistakes as they face jail time in this flawed but intriguing documentary produced by Terrence Malick</p><p>At the White Earth reservation in Minnesota, two Native American men at different points in their lives face down jail time and take stock of the mistakes they’ve made. The older man, a charismatic drug dealer named Rob Brown, is about to go to jail for a 57-month stretch, and prepares mentally for it by partying fiercely, taking leave of his pregnant girlfriend and dispensing some advice to his teenage protege, Kevin Fineday, who’s clearly on the same self-destructive path. This documentary, by the first-time director Jack Pettibone Riccobono, is a deep drink of bleak. But there are incidental moments of beauty or startling surreality to marvel at, such as the rippling magic-hour reflection of a silo in a pool of water, or a shot of a car burning while children play nearby, entirely unconcerned. Terrence Malick gets a credit for grandfathering the project, and it’s clear his poetic vision of the American midwest is an influence here – possibly a negative one, because its opening half hour is a mess.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2016/may/12/the-seventh-fire-review-documentary-terrence-malick-native-americans">Continue reading...</a></description>
